CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 18 (London Times dispatch)--Unofficial reports reaching Calcutta indicate that acts of violence are continuing on an alarming scale in the districts of Noakhali and Tippera.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association declared yesterday it is receiving "disquieting reports that some newspapers may be cut off entirely from a newsprint source at the end of this year."

Over the radio last night Secretary Byrnes made a report to the American people on the results of his work in Paris and on the work that remains to be done before a final treaty of peace is written. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18 --Alan H. Temple, a vice president and economist of the National City Bank of New York, said here today that the crest of the inflation spiral "must be" drawing near. He added that there is no necessity nor likelihood of "excessive disastrous deflation."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--The Civilian Production Administration announced today that soda ash, sorely needed in many essential industries, would be distributed according to the voluntary plan of distribution used during the war years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)--A priest event into court today in an effort to save one of his flock--a condemned soldier--from death. He won the first round.

KALGAN, China, Oct. 17 (Delayed)--Kalgan, which a week ago was the second capital of Communist China, today is a silent city. Many buildings were ruined by fires. A fourth of the population has fled into the mountains of Mongolia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18-- William M. Ivins Jr., curator emeritus of prints at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, tonight called the founding of an art gallery at Yale University in 1832 a step which some day may be regarded "as one of the major contributions made by Yale to the theory and practice of academic education."

OMAHA, Oct. 18 (AP)--Because the United States is not taking care of its soil, this country is "moving exactly along the path which brought ruin to Chinese government, economy and civilization," Louis Bromfield said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Commerce Department said today that although the all-time high of business inventories "do not now appear to be excessive" the situation has dangerous potentialities and could result in serious readjustments.

LONDON, Oct. 18--The world's displaced persons, dislodged by World War II, will be eligible Jan. 15 for a "travel document," carrying many advantages of a passport, the Intergovernmental Committee for Refugees announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 (AP)-- Frank Parker of San Francisco, 1945 United States tennis champion, entered the final of the PanAmerican singles championship today by defeating Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood, 6--2, 6--1, 2--6, 6--8, 12--10.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 18--After a ten-day lull the terrorists resumed their sniping and land mine-laying campaign last night with the murder of a British police inspector here and the promiscuous distribution of mines throughout other parts of Palestine.

ALBANY, Oct. 18.--Seven appointments and reappointments to professional boards and the granting of charters to educational institutions were announced by the State Board of Regents today.

VIENNA, Oct. 18--Austria is using up this year's harvest at such a rate that by the middle of next month one-fourth or more is expected to be gone. Jittery over the defection of three big food chains from the ranks of hold-out truck operators, representatives of eighty large trucking companies voted yesterday afternoon to set up a system of financial penalties to discourage further breaks in their resistance to the Bohack wage formula.

In keeping with current practice among banks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has announced a 10 per cent increase for all its 4,000 employes and certain junior officers, it was learned yesterday.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 21 (AP)--American constabulary troopers, equipped with tanks and machine guns and aided by German police, seized fifty-five Germans tonight in two lightning raids in search of anti-denazification terrorists who exploded three bombs here on Saturday.

BOSTON, Oct. 21--Warning that the shoe industry faces its most critical period, spokesmen said today at the opening of the Boston shoe show that normal production cannot be achieved until spring even with prompt decontrol of leather, hides and shoes.

The Hercules Powder Company reported in its nine-month statement ended with Sept. 30 net earnings of $5,631,636 after all charges and $3,619,675 taxes. This is equal after preferred dividend payments to $2.01 each on the 2,633,420 shares of common stock outstanding during the period.
Gracefully wrought silverware, hand-made by the Danish craftsman Frantz Hingelberg, is being presented for the first time in New York in a new silver department opened yesterday at B. Altman Co.
PARMACHENE LAKE, Me., Oct. 21--Six weary hunters are back in camp tonight. There is no venison for supper, but not every day of deer hunting is a successful day so far as the kill is concerned.

Between $35,000 and $40,000 in jewelry was stolen last Thursday night from an eleventh floor suite of the Hotel Madison, 15 East Fifty-eighth Street, occupied by Mrs. Allan S. Lehman, a niece of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman by marriage, and her British guest, Lady Scarsdale, the police disclosed yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 22--Camp No. 61 at Caraolos, outside Famagusta in Cyprus, was made ready today for the reception of 819 Jewish refugee men, women and children who were deported from Palestine this morning. The refugees had arrived on the intercepted blockade runner Braha Fuld.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 22 --Attacking the voting record of his Republican opponent, Senator H. Alexander Smith, George E. Brunner, Democratic candidate for Senator, told an audience of Perth Amboy voters tonight that Senafor Smith had received a campaign contribution from Joseph N. Pew Jr. of Pennsylvania.

Memorial services, parades, aerial displays, and social gatherings are among the activities that will mark the twenty-fifth observance of Navy Day in twenty major ports and hundreds of communities on Sunday.

Deputy Mayor Thomas L. J. Corcoran intervened last night to avert a strike of 7,000 Western Union telegraph workers in this city, scheduled for midnight tonight.

Trading in the cotton market eased back yesterday into a more normal pattern. Under aggressive mill buying, prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange moved steadily upward after an early recession and closed virtually at the best levels of the day, with net gains of 108 to 133 points, or $5.40 to $6.65 a bale.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 22--Officials of the Chinese Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, distributors of UNRRA supplies in China, voiced disappointment today over F.H. La Guardia's order authorizing a partial lifting of the restrictions imposed in July on the shipment of UNRRA supplies to China.

Larry Cisneros, 139, Los Angeles, won a decision over Joey Varoff, 136, East Side, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. The Californian scored repeatedly with lefts and rights to his foe's head and body.

Somewhat tardy in commencing its fourth season, the successful Equity Library Theatre, a show case for up-and-coming actors, is about to swing into action. Scheduled to start early last month, activities were delayed because of administrative differences. Now that everything has been amicably adjusted, plays, directors and casts are being lined up by Sam Jaffe for a series of free performances on the miniature stages of public libraries.

Net profit of the American Woolen Company for the nine months ended with September was $16,259,000, compared with $4,540,000 in the first nine months of last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22-- Paramount today borrowed Anne Baxter from Twentieth CenturyFox to play the feminine lead in "Blaze of Noon," which John Farrow will direct from Ernest K. Gann's novel about airmail aviation.

Bobby Layne's passing arm, an important cog in the workings of Texas University's powerful gridiron machine, finally has lifted the Longhorn fullback to the position of offensive leader among the college football players of the nation.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 22 (UP)-- Landlords who control most of Seattle's apartment houses went on a "renting strike" today by pledging themselves to refuse to re-rent their 21,200 apartments until rent ceilings are abolished.

The United States will propose to the United Nations General Assembly an immediate survey to determine Europe's relief needs after the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration ends its work.

A plan for an International Council of Christians and Jews received yesterday the unanimous approval of the board of directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

Following three weeks of training at the Nevele Country Club, Ellenville, N.Y., the New York Knickerbockers, Madison Square Garden's entry in the new Basketball Association of America, arrived in the city yesterday.

The eyes of the world today are on New York, where fifty-one nations gather in the General Assembly of the United Nations to continue the great adventure in international cooperation that must be the foundation of peace and prosperity.

PEIPING, Oct. 22--Analysis of the military picture in China shows that, although the Communists have been forced to abandon important cities such as Kalgan, Chengteh, Chihfeng and Tsining and numerous smaller communities, they still command vital areas.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22--The defeat of Liberal party candidates and the loss yesterday of two former Liberal seats in the Federal Parliament have created a delicate situation for Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King and his Cabinet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22--Charles Connard Hanch, automobile industry pioneer, who had been an inventor, a writer and automotive business counsel, died here today in his home of a cerebral hemorrhage after several weeks of illness. His age was 78.

DECATUR, Ala., Oct. 22--Shipbuilding, usually the white elephant of reconversion from war to peace economy, is beginning to play again a sizable part in the industrial life of this river port, 1,300 miles from the open sea. Its revival is actually five months behind schedule, because of the steel and coal strikes which delayed delivery of materials.

Hilda Andino's first Carnegie Hall piano recital last night was evidently a big event for her native Puerto Rico. Arrangements were made to pipe her performances over a direct radio telephone line to the local CBS station in San Juan, the island's capital.
LONDON, Oct. 22--The Bank of England has again confirmed to the London silver market that there is no possibility whatever of India being allowed to buy silver for dollars.

Inadequate and unskilled personnel is largely responsible for cargo congestion at the Port of New York, port officials told a meeting of the National Council of American Importers, Inc., yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Astor.

LEXINGTON, Miss., Oct. 22 (AP) --After ten minutes' deliberation a Holmes County jury tonight acquitted five white men charged with manslaughter in the death of a Negro farm hand whom they admitted whipping two days before his beaten body was found floating in a bayou.

FOR more than a month the greatest guessing game of them all has been under way in sports. It was--and is--who's going to manage the Yankees? During the world series this was a constant topic of discussion among the Gentlemen of the Press.

In the housing shortage for veterans we have also been laboring under a shortage of dependable facts. This has been somewhat alleviated now by the release of results of a survey made in July by the Census Bureau at the request of the National Housing Agency.

BERLIN, Oct. 22--Meat stocks in the European theatre for the Army and civilians will last for forty-seven days at the present rate, including 2,000,000 pounds due to be shipped on Oct. 25, Gen. Joseph T. McNarney said today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 (AP)--Daniel Upthegrove, former chief executive officer and corporate president of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt Railroad), died here early today at St. Luke's Hospital.

Even though in one household it has caused a husband-and-wife political rift, a large volunteer women's group, its workers drawn from all sections of the Eighteenth Congressional District, has been organized in support of the campaign of Frederick V.P. Bryan, Republican. Mr. Bryan is opposing the incumbent, Representative Vito Marcantonio, Democratic and American Labor Candidate.

LONDON, Oct 22 (AP)--The War Office announced tonight that Lieut. Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker would relinquish his post as commander of British forces in Palestine soon to head the Army's Eastern Command it England.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22-- Listening to Charley Caldwell, one might get an idea that Princeton's football team is headed for a sorry afternoon, come Saturday at Palmer Stadium, where the young Tigers are to grapple with Cornell, which grew in stature as the result of holding Yale even last week.
New York will extend a vociferous welcome today to approximately 400 delegates and alternates to the General Assembly of the United Nations, including representatives of all fifty-one member states.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--The question of whether the United States will accord diplomatic recognition to Bulgaria will be determined later, Secretary of State Byrnes declared at his news conference today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22--Sir Henry Hallett Dale of the Royal Society of London warned the nations of the world tonight that if they did not free science in peace from the secrecy which it accepted as a necessity of war they would "poison its very spirit" and destroy its promise of a harvest of human prosperity, culture and happiness.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22--White-collar workers are moving from offices to factories to fill what the newspaper Trud described today as a "serious lack of qualified workers."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--A strike of 400,000 soft coal miners on Nov. 1, four days before the Congressional elections, was obliquely threatened late today by John L. Lewis in his labor contract dispute with the Government.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 22-- Governor Thomas E. Dewey accused his political adversaries tonight of employing "fantastic and cruel" misrepresentations of the facts in an effort to delude voters.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 22-- The blazing glory of the rolling countryside, displayed in a daz zling panoply of rich autumnal colors from the vantage point of the hilltop practice field at Holy Cross, brought no answering sparkle to the eyes of Coach John Da Grosa today.

The National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, meeting today in Seattle, will demand that the Office of Price Administration authorize immediate decontrol, Fred W. Ritter, secretary of the New York Lumber Trades Association, disclosed yesterday.
The rapid expansion of the veteran's job-training program has placed greater responsibility on State agencies to insure proper standards, George L. Glasheen, ...
An exhibition of heirlooms from northern New Jersey homes was opened last night at the Newark Museum with a preview and dinner for the thirty-two lenders.

Breakfast at 9 A.M. in the mountains of Nyasaland in Africa --preceded by five hours of hunting for rare game--was the routine described yesterday by Arthur S. Vernay, trustee of the American Museum of Natural History on his return from a five-month expedition in the area.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 22-- While the Army team dug in for a rugged sixty-minute scrimmage that took in offensive as well as defensive play, Coach Earl Blaik sought ways and means to slow up the powerful single-wing attack employed invariably by Wallace Wade, whose Duke Blue Devils will oppose the Cadets at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

Assorted artificers, charwomen, furniture handlers and perspiring porters swarmed through the General Assembly Hall in Flushing Meadow Park yesterday getting the great chamber ready for the United Nations.

An Englishman orders whisky and soda, an Italian vermouth, a Scandinavian aquavit, a Russian vodka and an American--well, almost anything that combines many things. Our taste for mixing alcoholic beverages is known the globe around; the cocktail is as much a part of the national scene as the World Series and the drug store that sells everything except refrigerators.

Delegates from fifty-one countries will convene in the New York City Building at Flushing Meadow Park at 4 P.M. today in the opening meeting of the second part of the first session of the United Nations General Assembly. President Truman will address the delegates at 4:30. [1:8.]

Pointing up its demands for a $1,000 salary increase for teachers, the Teachers Interest Committee of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx made public yesterday answers to questionnaires submitted to the school's staff.

A combined trade drive by both Great Britain and the United States to open up new markets through full employment and full production was advocated yesterday by Moir Mackenzie, deputy director general of the Federation of British Industries.
There was more meat, butter, poultry and eggs available yesterday in New York's retail shops than housewives had seen in several months, and milk distribution was on a more even basis, too.

With the possible exceptions of Cecil Hare and Phil Ragazzo, there was a chance yesterday that the New York Football Giants would be at full strength for next Sunday's National League game with the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--President Truman urged today that the scope of the National School Lunch Act, passed in June, be spread until "the lunches are available in every community in every state and territory."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22-- Starting the second week of his up-State campaign for the United States Senate, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman told a gathering in Watertown High School tonight that he backed the St. Lawrence seaway plan as a vital step in defense of the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--Four labor unions which have challenged the right of the House Campaign Expenditures Committee to inquire into their plans for political action and spending were invited today to have spokesmen in Washington for questioning on Monday.

The entrance hall is one place where homemakers should concentrate their decorating talents and use color schemes that give a "lift" to the person entering the door, Florence Terhune, interior decoration lecturer for Macy's, declared yesterday.
The appointment of a committee to consider the recent banning of the recitation of the Lord's Prayer in Flushing High School and Brooklyn Technical High School was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)-- The Office of Price Administration mixed good and bad news for consumers today.
PARMACHENE LAKE, Mo., Oct. 22--Although we had no game for our opening day dinner, the menu for tonight will include venison, grouse and duck, with a wild cranberry sauce to improve the flavor.

The stock market definitely returned to the lower side yesterday, when selling in the steels and motors spread to other sections of the list and left industrial issues depressed approximately a point at the close.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 22 --Westchester County was tentatively approved today as the world capital of the United Nations. The Headquarters Commission described that suburban area as a "convenient, attractive and otherwise suitable site" for permanent headquarters.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 22-- A man's second wife, or his third or fourth for that matter, has a right not only to be buried in the family lot provided by her husband, but also to have her name inscribed with his on the family gravestone.

Independent peddlers of soft drink beverages are proper subjects for unionization and members of a union cannot be compelled to service non-union peddlers, the Appellate Division of the Second Department ruled yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 22-- Willis Kingsley Gillette of this city, a retired Supreme Court justice, who had been active in the civic life of Monroe County for half a century, died here last night in St. Mary's Hospital, after having been in ill health for a year. His age was 80.

Swedish advocates of cartel and Bilateral trade with Russia are laying the ground for nationalization of their businesses, Herbert H. Schell, chairman of the International Economic Relations Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday.

Reflecting an increase of 64 per cent in sales for the third quarter over the corresponding period of last year, net earnings of the National Gypsum Company totaling $1,114,824 were almost four times larger than the $290,029 net of a year ago, according to the report of Melvin H. Baker, president, issued to stockholders yesterday.
The CIO Political Action Committee "thoroughly disavowed" yesterday any foreign influence or interference in the election as "completely unwarranted."
The New York County Lawyers Association announced yesterday that it found both candidates for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals "well qualified."

BERLIN, Oct. 22--The belief that the Berlin elections on Sunday represented primarily an expression of dissent from the present situation was expressed today by Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, United States Military Governor of Germany.

Only one airplane bearing the red arrow of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., flew over the world-wide system of the country's fourth largest airline yesterday on the second day of the pilots' strike for higher wages.

MONTREAL, Oct. 22 (AP)--National Hockey League statistics today showed Syd Abel, speedy forward of the Detroit Red Wings, leading the individual scoring parade with live points, consisting of two goals and three assists accumulated in his team's three games.
PARIS, Oct. 22--The reports from the provinces indicate that in the national election on Nov. 10 there will be about 2,500 candidates for the 544 seats in the new National Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--A political science class at Swarthmore College tonight heard from O. John Rogge, special Assistant to the Attorney General, a detailed account of efforts which Hermann Goering, Joachim von Ribbentrop and other high Nazi officials say they made to defeat President Roosevelt for re-election in 1936, 1940 and 1944.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 22--Members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, employed at Public Service Electrical and Gas Company plants, were assured today by Gov. Walter E. Edge that the utility concern had not made operating changes to which they objected.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 22-- A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters of the American Federation of Labor and chairman of a provisional committee to organize Negro locomotive firemen, said at a meeting of Negro firemen held here that the brotherhoods of operating trainmen "have worked and fought with violence, law and contracts" to make the railroads "a lily-white industry."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--Restoration of the New York Foreign Trade Zone to two of its former five piers at Stapleton, S.I., was authorized today by W.A. Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, acting as chairman of the Foreign Trade Zones Board of the United States. It was predicted officially that the Army would relinquish the remaining three piers by the end of the year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 22 (AP) --Buster Tyler, 142 pounds, of Newark, N.J., rallied from a near knockout in the first round to score an amazing upset victory over Beau Jack, Negro welterweight title contender, from Augusta, Ga., in a ten-round bout tonight at the Armory. Jack weighed 142 .
Striking engineering officers of the merchant marine will vote today and tonight on a new contract negotiated with shipping employers of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--Secretary of State Byrnes reasserted today that the United States would continue to expect deeds, not words, from Argentina in eradicating Nazi influences and otherwise qualifying for a place in the American community of nations.

It now appears that the Board of Estimate will vote this week a pay rise of nearly $20,000,000 to transit employes while the transit system itself is running in the red by about three times that much annually.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 22-- With an anti-national Administration trend clearly visible in Connecticut, the election of the Republican State ticket headed by Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin for United States Senator and Dr. James L. McConaughy for Governor by sizable pluralities is indicated.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22--Georgi M. Malenkov, 45, has been named one of the eight vice chairmen of the Council of Ministers of the U.S. S.R., Pravda stated today.
The Board of Estimate will approve tomorrow a resolution providing a salary increase totaling $18,500,000 for the city's 33,000 transit employes, Deputy Mayor L.J. Corcoran announced late yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 22--The Argentine Government has cut off almost all food shipments for Bolivia, which depends upon Argentina for about 70 per cent of her food, since the military dictatorship of Maj. Gualberto Villarroel was deposed and democratic elements took control of this landlocked South American republic.
LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP)--Excerpts from Foreign Secretary Bevin's speech opening the House of Commons debate on British foreign policy:
The decision of the Alleghany Corporation to reduce further at this time its holdings of common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway has come as a surprise to the financial community.
American observers of China's long struggle toward internal peace are learning that appearances there are seldom what they seem.
WHEN Mary O'Hara wrote "My Friend Flicka" she brought joy into the hearts of thousands of delighted readers who took that lovely story of a small boy and his horse to their hearts.

France became the third Government to submit information about non-self-governing territories under its administration yesterday when Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, disclosed that Premier-President Bidault had transmitted data on a long list of French possessions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--Secretary of State Byrnes said today he would not object to continuing in Europe the Big Four discussion of Germany that will start in New York.

NANKING Oct. 22--A seventeen-point program for administration of areas recovered from the Communists has been enacted by the Supreme National Defense Council, sovereign organ of China's one-party State.
The forthcoming meeting of the United Nations General Assembly may mark the beginning of peace, according to Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--An increase of 134 per cent in meat production by Federally inspected plants during the first week that price controls were off was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.

James G. Blaine, president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, called for "dynamic unity" and more effective group action to meet the challenge of welfare problems in an address last night to 500 representatives of 200 Protestant welfare agencies.
The card at Jamaica did not present any standout names yesterday, but it did produce racing that was enjoyed by a crowd of 21,718.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 22-- This is the broad, over-all political question in California today, two weeks before the election:
Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, defended yesterday the right of the Moscow radio to broadcast its preference for "progressive" candidates backed by the CIO Political Action Committee.
Three additional companies abandoned yesterday the ranks of hold-out truck operators, permitting the recall of 2,000 laid-off industrial workers.

Howard Walter McAteer, president for nearly a quarter of a century of the American Steel Export Company, Inc., died in his home at 270 Park Avenue yesterday, after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 22--A 3 to 1 affirmative opinion was reached here today on the question "Can We Get Along With Russia?" by members of a panel on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum. The program, presented before 650 members of the Woman's Club of Orange and broadcast over WQXR, was another in the weekly series "What's On Your Mind?"

A letter written by Dr. William S. Ladd in 1940, when he was dean of Cornell Medical College, in which he said that "we limit the number of Jews admitted to each class to roughly the proportion of Jews in the population in this State," was submitted yesterday to a special City Council committee.

DETROIT, Oct. 22--Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, presented to the assembly of the United States chapter of the International College of Surgeons tonight a four-point program for enduring peace based upon the principle of full preparedness for any eventuality.

There was little change in the relative position of the nations on ship production during the quarter ended Sept. 30, although the volume of merchant vessels being built throughout the world increased, according to a report issued yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 22--The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today turned over its epidemiological functions to the United Nations World Health Organization.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 22 (U.P.)--Some 75,000 workers staged a fifteen-minute mass protest strike today against the "reactionary circles and former Nazis" who, they believed, perpetrated Saturday night's bomb attacks here and in near-by Backnang.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 22-- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, returned to New Delhi yesterday after a weekend at Bagpat. He had a fiftyminute interview with the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, today.

Three New York real estate men, all former Navy officers, are among a crew of nine who are scheduled to leave here next month on a cruise aboard the late Capt. Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett's famous twomasted schooner, the Effie M. Morrissey, it was learned yesterday.

The international chess masters tournament in Prague, which was decided before the final round in favor of Mendel Najdorf of Poland when he drew a game of extraordinary length with Jan Foltys of Czechoslovakia, was concluded yesterday with seven games in the thirteenth round, according to reports from Czechoslovakia.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 22-- Profound differences between the trade union movements in Britain and the Soviet Union were shown here today at the seventy-eighth annual Conference of the Trades Union Congress.

The words of advice Coach Lou Little gave his Columbia football players Monday were put into action for two and a half hours yesterday at Baker Field. For the first time all year the first-string line proved capable of stopping thrusts at its vulnerable guard and tackle positions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22--The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to organize a new company, to be known as the Southern Company, as a step in its program for compliance with the corporate simplification and geographic integration requirements of the Holding Company Act.

Plans for making available to home-seeking families 10,000 apartments and bungalows in resort areas are being placed in the hands of local rent authorities, it was disclosed yesterday by Milton Krochmal, District Office of Price Administration rent executive.

WIESBADEN, Oct. 22--At the end of the month there will be opened in this crumbling town, once a well-known health resort and now the capital of the new German state called Greater Hesse, an industry and trade exhibition designed to show the few foreign visitors who can break into Germany and multitudes of Germans who can't break out the potential capacity of this small but densely populated province to produce for peace.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP)--Phillips Lee Goldsborough, Republican Governor of Maryland from 1912 to 1916 and United State Senator from 1929 to 1935, died here today in Union Memorial Hospital. His age was 81. He had undergone an operation ten days ago.

BERLIN, Oct. 22--The rebellious attitude of the majority of the Ruhr coal miners against fulfillment of the agreement their leaders made with the Military Government to work Sunday shifts to provide fuel for domestic heating this winter may result in the collapse of the plan.

Plans for a 796-apartment cooperative housing project underthe sponsorship of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York will be offered for approval of the Board of Estimate at its next meeting, it was announced yesterday.

The United Nations General Assembly will convene at Flushing Meadow Park at 4 P.M. today amid general but restrained hope that it will avoid the bitter quarrels of other recent gatherings of the wartime allies.

Army, which gained added prestige by its 48--14 thumping of Columbia, was installed more firmly than ever as the nation's outstanding collegiate gridiron power today by writers who voted in The Associated Press' weekly poll to select the ten top teams.

BERLIN, Oct. 22--A proposal, backed by the United States, for decentralization of the five largest German banks and the simultaneous creation of an Allied banking board and a German central banking commisson has been dropped from the agenda of the Allied Control Council, it was announced today. Russia had declined to support the plan.

The four-month old Philippine Republic will initiate a small-nation fight in the General Assembly to dilute the power of the veto, according to Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, head of the delegation from Manila.

Mob scenes developed yesterday at many A. P. Food Markets. As the chain's 486 metropolitan stores, closed since Sept. 14 because of the trucking strike, prepared to reopen yesterday morning, extra police were needed in some areas to control the crowds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)-- Some of the "extreme ease" that prevailed in the wartime money market has gone, but "basic easy credit conditions" have not been altered, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

Their 6-year-old son, Charles Jr., who was recovering from chicken-pox, saw the shooting.

Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee and of the Greater New York United Jewish Appeal, will leave today by plane for Europe, it was announced yesterday. He will survey the relief, rehabilitation and resettlement needs of Jewish survivors of the Nazi regime.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., former internationalist, yesterday was elected chairman of the United States Polo Association at the first meeting of the organization since before the war. The meeting, held at the Racquet and Tennis Club, officially started the reorganization of the sport which, until the past summer, was completely dormant during the war years.
Foreign Minister Molotov threw Russia's support yesterday behind a sudden Polish move to open the way for action on Spain in the United Nations General Assembly.
To his Excellency, Mr. Trygve Lie, Secretary-General of the United Nations, New York.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 30 (AP)-- Gunnar Jahn, chairman of the Nobel Peace Prize Committee, said lion a published report in Copenhagen that it already had been decided that Madame Kollontay would receive the prize. Announcement of the award is expected Nov. 6.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Col. Myron R. Wood, Chief of Supply of the Army Air Forces, died last night of a heart attack at his home here. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--President Truman pledged today to Representative John J. Sparkman of Alabama all aid the Government could give in an attempt to stabilize the cotton market. Prices have dropped $50 a bale since Oct. 8.

Measures taken during his administration to eliminate discrimination in employment because of race, religion or national origin were emphasized last night by Governor Dewey as he began in New York City the final phase of his campaign for re-election.

Charging that "Austria is under the most oppressive occupation in Europe," Dr. Karl Gruber, her Foreign Minister, named "mounting difficulties with the Soviet occupation power" last night as the principal reason for Austria's demand for the outright abolition of the occupation.
ROME, Oct. 30--After a few months of comparative plenty following the last harvest, which was unusually abundant, Italy again faces the prospect of a wheat shortage in the not very distant future.

Michigan State Normal College awarded yesterday an issue of $1,030,000 serial and term dormitory revenue bonds to the First of Michigan Corporation and associates. The issue was resold at a range of offering prices to yield from 1 to 2.15 per cent for serials maturing from 1947 to 1958, and from 2 to 2.25 per cent for term bonds coming due in 1958 and 1963.
Estimates of changes in cost of living during the war and transition years usually make allowance for several factors which have not been measured adequately in the index.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Ten publications purporting to give "under-cover" access to non-existent or reserved surplus war property at "below cost" are under investigation by the Government, the War Assets Administration disclosed tonight.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (AP)-- Warren C. Giles has a new fiveyear contract as general manager of the Reds.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct.30--Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce, declared tonight that Secretary of State James F. Byrnes has been "needled" into risking war with Russia by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg and the War and Navy Departments.

Recent abolition of import duties on Canadian lumber will not result in increased supplies from hundreds of war-born Eastern Canadian mills, northeastern industry spokesmen said yesterday. Bulk of such shipments, it was declared, are going to more lucrative markets in the British Empire.

NANKING, Oct. 30 (U.P.)--Government troops have made four amphibious landings near Chefoo and other armies are reported marching toward the Communist stronghold of Harbin, Manchuria's largest industrial center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized rate increases for the Railway Express Agency which will yield an estimated $58,876,440 a year in additional revenue. The new rates are to offset what it called "the increased costs of operation."

BERLIN, Oct. 30--The first positive step in the bi-zonal approach to economic problems was taken when the British agreed to furnish 5,000 extra tons of motor fuel next month to help meet the transportation crisis in the American zone, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP)--A flurry of second period scoring which netted four goals in 4 minutes 21 seconds tonight gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 5-to-2 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks in a National Hockey League game before 17,736 persons at the Stadium.

W. Averell Harriman, recently appointed Secretary of Commerce, discounted last night fears of economic disaster ahead in this country. "I feel strongly," he said, "that these fears are based on unreasoning defeatism."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30--The Argentine fleet that is on the way to Chile for the inauguration of President-elect Gabriel Gonzalez Videla will beat the United States naval force to Valparaiso by one day.

Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, announced last night the receipt of two communications from the Albanian Government charging an invasion of Albanian waters by British warships and border incursions by "Greek Monarchist-Fascists."

Non-recurring profits of $12,720,000 on the sale of securities swelled the net income of the Aviation Corporation in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 to $13,147,025 from the $2,159,739 in the corresponding period of last year, the report disclosed yesterday.

In support of the sixty-eighth annual United Hospital Campaign, members of the women's committee staged a rally during the noon hour yesterday at the United States Sub-Treasury Building on Wall Street.

Trading on the principal cotton futures markets throughout the country was halted suddenly yesterday for the third time in the last eleven days. The lead of the New York Cotton Exchange in shutting down its machinery was followed quickly by New Orleans and Chicago, but the Dallas, Tex., market remained open.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30--Twentysix officers and members of the Allis-Chalmers Workers Union, Local 248 of the United Auto Workers, CIO, today were ordered to appear in Milwaukee Circuit Court at 2 P.M. Friday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Disposal of surplus war property in the third quarter of 1946 dropped 25 per cent below the previous quarter as the War Assets Administration worked under a double handicap, the agency reported to Congress today.

In a highly imaginative scene, called "The Bootblack's Dream," in "Fashions of the Times," the ensembling of costume and shoes was stressed. The stage device for exhibiting shoes so that the entire audience might see them was a new one in fashion show technique.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 30 --Art Littleton, rangy left end, today was appointed captain of the Pennsylvania team for Saturday's game with Princeton.

Despite Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's warning that elimination of the veto would mean liquidation of the United Nations, several smaller powers continued to criticize the Security. Council's voting system yesterday before the General Assembly session at Flushing Meadow.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30--Lewis G. Hansen, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, declared in a speech here tonight that his Republican opponent, Alfred E. Driscoll, was making a campaign based on "deceit and hypocrisy." He spoke at an Essex County Democratic Club rally in Essex House.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--A possible five-point understatement in the consumers' price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics will be overcome in a few months, in the opinion of bureau economists.

LONDON, Oct. 30--Delegates of seventeen nations have virtually agreed at their meeting here on a trade charter covering the major topics of cartels, commodity agreements and commitments by member nations to stabilize employment.
Dr. John P. Simmons, Professor of Chemistry at New York University for twenty years, died at his home in Great Barrington, Mass., on Tuesday night. He was 66 years old.
Yugoslavia, to no one's surprise, pledged her unqualified support yesterday to the proposals for disarmament and banning of the atomic bomb made on Tuesday by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman summed up the objectives of liberals and progressives in seventy words last night as he spoke between 8:45 and 9 o'clock over radio station WMCA under American Labor party sponsorship in his campaign for the Senate.

In a strongly worded attack upon Governor Dewey's claim to liberalism, Senator James M. Mead and former Governor Herbert H. Lehman charged last night that the Governor "cultivated an appearance of liberal leadership merely as a cloak" with which to cover his reactionary interests.
A fashion show within a fashion show makes one of the most interesting scenes in "Fashions of the Times," now being presented in two daily performances at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 (AP)-- More than 300 naval officers and enlisted men assigned to the Eighth Naval District will don their dungarees tomorrow and man the city's garbage trucks, in answer to a second call for volunteers issued by Mayor de Lesserps S. Morrison today.
Re-education of the children of Europe must follow physical rehabilitation, according to Mrs. Margit Levinson, president of Raedda Barnen, Sweden's leading child welfare agency.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30--A revolutionary advance in television, involving the reproduction of colors entirely by electronic means, was demonstrated here today by the Radio Corporation of America.
The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of Eugene E. Wilson as vice chairman of the board. He will continue, however, as a director.

An increase of 55 per cent in sales by the General Motors Corporation during the third quarter of this year produced a net profit of $33,816,460, equal to 71 cents a share on the common stock, the corporation disclosed yeaterday in its quarterly report to stockholders. Baron Maurice E.C. de Rothschild embarked yesterday for Europe after six years of Nazi-im posed exile. The member of the French banking family described America as the "greatest potential factor in the world today."

A strike of 7,000 Western Union telegraph workers in this city, scheduled for 12:01 A.M. today, was averted four hours before the deadline last night through the efforts of a special committee appointed by Deputy Mayor Thomas L.J. Corcoran.
VIENNA, Oct. 30--Parliament unanimously instructed Chancellor Leopold Figl today to press for the restoration of Austria's full sovereignty, including the end of the Allies' occupation.

The news from Detroit, where "If the Shoe Fits" recently had its world premiere, is that the Leonard Sillman musical production shapes up as a potential Broadway hit. Several Detroit reviewers characterized the entertainment as "one of the most refreshing shows ...

Within twenty-four hours President William D. Cox of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers of the AllAmerica Conference will reveal the identity of the team's new coach. At least, that is Cox's intention. It will be recalled that, following the "resignation" of Mal Stevens, the club thought it had Fred Linehan set to take over, but the latter apparently changed his plans at the last minute.

PARIS, Oct. 30--Premier-President Georges Bidault apparently succeeded today in removing the threat of a peasants' revolt in wine-growing southeastern France by negotiating a modified agreement with the producers, which the Cabinet approved.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30--Wide use of home and farm freezer units will greatly change seasonal chores of housewives, J.B. Hennion, an official of the Tyler Fixture Corporation of Niles, Mich., said today at the "All Industry Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Exposition" at Public Hall.

Haire of 1120 Fifth Avenue, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Grattan.

For the third consecutive day a new high temperature mark was set here yesterday as the mercury reached 78.8 degrees and New Yorkers continued to shed coats and jackets in the warmest October on record.

Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade repudiated last night a circular sent to principals and teachers in New York City public schools by a Board of Education official. The circular urged consumers to "refrain from buying" at inflated prices.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 --Local parent-teacher associations were urged today by Mrs. Harold D. Stewart of Hillside, president of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers, to redouble their efforts to mold public opinion to support legislation for vastly increased funds for education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--The Civil Aeronautics Administration's proposed regulatory provisions with reference to the construction of airports on Federally aided projects were approved, with one exception, in a statement presented at a CAA hearing today by the Associated General Contractors of America.

The possibility that the Liberal party might have to cancel its Manhattan Center rally last night or expose James M. Mead, Herbert H. Lehman and the party's own leaders to the embarrassment of crossing a picket line was averted by settlement of a strike of the center's guards late yesterday afternoon.

The fifth annual chorale of meow, purr and caterwaul was opened yesterday by the BrooklynLong Island Cat Show in cooperation with the Siamese Cat Society of America, Inc., in the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Faced by the loss of United States support of a world food board, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization was prepared today to accept a compromise plan more compatible with this Government's over-all foreign trade policy.

An increase of 493,000 barrels in the nation's stocks of gasoline was made last tveek, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks at the week-end amounted to 86,423,000 barrels, against 85,930,000 a week earlier and 74,514,000 on Oct. 27, 1945.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.)--The Moscow radio said tonight that Soviet officials in Korea want to resume "as soon as possible" joint discussions with United States authorities on the establishment of a democratic provisional government for Korea under Allied trusteeship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--On the eve of the coal dispute conference between the Coal Mines Administration and the United Mine Workers, the Government agency today ruled in favor of retroactive vacation payments to the miners.

When President Truman appointed David E. Lilienthal to be chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission one of his problems was to find a man to replace Mr. Lilienthal as head of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Sixteen thousand teachers, parents, business men and labor leaders attended a mass meeting last night in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, to demand permanent salary increases of $1,050 a year for all teachers and staff members of the city's school system.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 31-- One thousand and forty-five furniture buyers from all parts of the country registered at the furniture building here today at the opening of the five-day fall market featuring ten new exhibitors but few changes in design.

M. tomorrow in the office of Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler.
Renewed efforts by the City Labor Relations Division to settle the seven-week strike of 3,000 United Parcel Service drivers, helpers and inside workers met with little success last night.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 31--The current struggle for spheres of influence between the United States and Russia is a concession to the Republicans, Henry A. Wallace, former Secretary of Commerce, declared in a talk here tonight at the annual convention of the Wisconsin Association of Cooperatives.

While bulldozers leveled ground for new concrete runways, Richard H. Gans, 28-year-old ex-captain in the Army Transportation Corps, said yesterday he expected completion of his 135-acre airport for private planes at Eltingville, S.I., by next April 1.

A nation-wide search for a superintendent of schools for New York City has been narrowed down to four names, two from this city's school system and two from other cities, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31-- The Central Assembly, acting on a Government motion, referred to a select committee of the House today a bill providing for the compulsory recognition of "representative" trade unions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31--Strength in cotton furnished the background for aggressive short-covering in grain futures on the Board of Trade today. Corn and oats ran up around cents a bushel from the early low, while wheat showed a firm undertone.
The five-story residence of Martin F. and Claire L. Emory at 3 East Ninety-fourth Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been sold to a buyer for occupancy through the Madison Realty Company, brokers.

The United Nations General Assembly, in an unexpected and welcome burst of speed, completed the initial stage of its plenary sessions yesterday and prepared for committee discussions of the Soviet disarmament proposal, the Franco regime in Spain and the fifty-four other items on its agenda.

Liquidation of an oversupply of more than 10,000,000 yards of undesirable upholstery and drapery fabrics by "drastic" mark-downs is necessary before a better type merchandise will become available, a manufacturers' spokesman declared yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 31--The police announced tonight that they had held and then released two suspects in the mysterious bombing that wrecked a wing of the British Embassy early today but injured none of the personnel.
YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 31--Leib Deyo of this city, purchasing agent and former president of the National Ski Association, died today in the Yonkers Professional Hospital at the age of 62.
Restoring parents' confidence in themselves is one of the main jobs of persons now working with children, Dr. Lawrence K. Frank said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31--Counsel for debenture holders and the indenture trustee of American Gas and Power Company today voiced vigorous objections to the company's modified reorganization plan in an oral argument before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prices of Southwest African Persian lambs declined 17 per cent from August levels at the sale of 143,535 skins held here yesterday by Eastwood Holt, Inc. Competition was good and there was 100 per cent turnover of the offering which brought approximately $1,200,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 31-- The Rev. Solomon Sadowsky, chief Orthodox Jewish rabbi in Rochester for more than a quarter of a century, died early today of a heart attack in his home. He had been in ill health for a year. His age was 67.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 31-- Dr. Wilbur A. Rayton, one of the nation's top-ranking optical engineers and head of the scientific bureau of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company here, died today of a heart attack while attending a convention in San Francisco of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers. Amid the cheers of a highly demonstrative audience, Senator James M. Mead called for the defeat of Governor Dewey last night at the "Everybody for Mead and Lehman" rally at Madison Square Garden on the ground that "the party of Hoover and Dewey, Taft and Reece is reaching out for labor's throat."

After an absence of seven weeks, boxing returns to Madison Square Garden tonight with Johnny Greco, Montreal welterweight, opposing Tony Pellone of Greenwich village in the feature bout of ten rounds.

New York City's total revenues for the fiscal year 1945-46 exceeded the budget, of any of the forty-eight States. According to the annual report of Controller Lazarus Joseph, the city's total revenue was $783,090,173.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year, consolidated net income of $12,843,050 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.88 a common share.

With the rising divorce rate a major problem, marriage counseling programs must be expanded, Frank J. Hertel, general director of the Family Service Association of America, declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening session of the association's biennial meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
