The chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the scene of the marriage yesterday afternoon of Miss Lela Harkness Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cook of 940 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I., to George Estabrook Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of 1172 Park Avenue.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 31--Comprehensive recommendations for economic recovery in the American and British zones were submitted to the joint Anglo-American military-government liaison officers by the bizonal German economics agency yesterday after a two-day meeting.

Only 10 per cent of more than 1,500 Queens residents in urgent need of treatment for speech and hearing defects can receive adequate care under existing facilities, Dr. Jon Eisenson, director of the Queens College Speech and Hearing Center, declared yesterday.

The loft buildings at 9 and 11 East Nineteenth Street and 895-99 Broadway, with an "L" through to 8 and 10 East Twentieth Street, have been purchased by Henry Goelet, operator, in a deal negotiated by Carstens Linnekin, Inc., brokers, subject to mortgages of $285,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 --Charles T. Purdy, wealthy White Plains sportsman and property owner accused of the fatal shooting last night of his wife, Mrs. Marie Shannon Purdy, was ar-- raigned today before Acting City Judge William McKinley on a charge of first-degree murder.
The United Nations General Assembly concluded general debate yesterday and adopted an agenda of fifty-six items for committee discussions opening at Lake Success today.

PEIPING, Oct. 31--As China's third parties strive in Nanking to arrange for a solution to the present civil war it can be authoritatively stated that the Nationalist war leaders are planning to unleash a full-scale assault on Communist-held Harbin approximately two weeks from today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31--George H. Cooley, a civic leader of Kankakee, Ill., died here today in his home, after a brief illness. His age was 73. He had been completely blind since 1897.

Most of the highway system now in use in this State was built for the "model T Ford era," Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday at the opening of the American Automobile Association building, 28 East Seventy-eighth Street, the new headquarters of the Automobile Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Disposal at about 22 cents on the dollar of overseas war material which originally cost $6,474,524,000 was reported to Congress today by James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State.

When the nation's principal cotton exchanges suspended trading on Wednesday of this week it marked the third time within a fortnight that such extreme action had been found necessary to restore order in this temporarily demoralized market.

The American Legion will oppose all plans to admit displaced persons to this country lest refugees deprive veterans of housing and jobs and "invite a flood tide of immigrants," Col. Paul H. Griffith, national commander of the Legion, declared here last night.

With Government controls on the way out, the cotton textile industry will be better able to step up production to meet vast accumulated demand, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday.
A team of six players, led by non-playing Captain Walter L. Pate of New York, will leave by plane for Australia Nov. 15 to challenge for the Davis cup.

Often in the money but rarely a winner, Darby Dan Farm's Darby Dunedin made her eighteenth start the occasion for her second 1946 success at Empire City-atJamaica yesterday when she showed the way to four others in the Class D Danbury Purse.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 --In a plea to reject the "cynicism and unconcern" with which many are greeting the United Nations, Sir Hartley Shawcross, British delegate to the United Nations Assembly, declared today that use of the veto would not be fatal to development of the new world organization.

Mr. and Mrs. Ranald Hugh Macdonald Jr. of 911 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Walton, to James Augustus Thomas, son of Mrs. James Augustus Thomas of 540 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Thomas.
Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for United States Senator, called upon Great Britain yesterday to lift its barriers so hundreds of thousands of Jews might go to Palestine.

ALBANY, Oct. 31--The five-mile section of Hempstead Turnpike between Hempstead and Queens Village, Nassau County, is to be modernized with a vitally needed system of traffic control facilities, it was announced today by Charles H. Sells, State Superintendent of Public Works. It is estimated this improvement will cost $74,000.
Impossible as it seems after weeks of shortages, the perishable food market has done an abrupt about-face, and consumers now hold the reins rather than retailers.
A 20-cent drop in porterhouse steak led a big break in retail meat prices here yesterday. The Department of Markets credited the reduction to the refusal of housewives to buy at higher prices.

Defining the real issue in his campaign for the United States Senate as a matter of whether his liberal record should prevail over "the gathering forces of reaction," former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman devoted a radio speech last night to a direct attack on Irving M. Ives, his Republican opponent.

Until the United States is willing to recognize the need for, and establish a universal system of elementary schools, it is doubtful that illiteracy can be eliminated here, Dr. Alonzo G. Grace, State Commissioner of Education for Connecticut, declared yesterday at the eleventh Educational Conference.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31-- Despite a cold shoulder from two East Chester Boards of Education and public officials in this Republican township, Elliott Roosevelt and his wife, the former Faye Emerson, made public appearances today in Bronxville, Tuckahoe and other areas of East Chester.
Youth in rebellion against the restrictive influences of modern society is the victim of an adult "conspiracy," Dr. Henry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, declared yesterday.
The Board of Education was urged yesterday to continue its support next summer of the cadet farm program created as an emergency measure during the war.

Two convicts who are serving long terms in the State Penitentiary in Joliet, Ill., were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of kidnapping Michael Reiter, 47-year-old dress manufacturer, in this city last June 30.
J.P. Lohman, former newspaper real estate editor who has been specializing in real estate and building publicity since 1938, has moved his office to 527 Fifth Avenue.

In at least one-third of sixty Bowery "flop-houses" investigated yesterday by the State Election Frauds Bureau, the proprietors could not identify some of their "tenants" who had registered for next Tuesday's election.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 --The Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology for 1946 was awarded tonight to Prof. Herman J. Muller, geneticist and member of the faculty of Indiana University at Bloomington, Ind.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31-- The President-elect of Chile, Gabriel Gonzalez Videla, today confirmed his pre-election pledges to the Communist party by giving its members three of the eleven seats in his Cabinet.
The President's appointments to the newly created Atomic Energy Commission have met, as they should, with general approval.

The American delegation to the London conference discussing a proposed International Trade Organization was urged to accept no compromise with principles and to make no sacrifices which are not matched by those of other nations, in a report prepared by the United States Associates and released today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--An examiner for the National Labor Relations Board upheld the International Typographical Union (AFL) today in its year-old strike against the St. Petersburg, Fla., Evening Independent and The Times.

EN ROUTE TO MISSOURI WITH PRESIDENT TRUMAN, Oct. 31--Across bright land lying quiet under the harvest, President Truman traveled tonight with sedate purposefulness, a citizen going home to Independence, Mo., to vote.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31--The big question confronting leaders of both political parties on the eve of President Truman's return to Missouri is whether the Congress of Indusrtial Organizations' Political Action Committee can again deliver enough Democratic votes ...

Election Day came a few days early to the Brooklyn College gridiron yesterday when, in a surprise move, Coach Lou Oshins decided to have his Kingsman squad choose the starters for tomorrow night's game with City College at Ebbets Field.

PARIS, Oct. 31--Frederic JoliotCurie, high commissioner for atomic energy and Nobel Prizewinning physicist, declared today that the United States should stop making atomic bombs and join the rest of the world in applying atomic energy to peaceful pursuits under civilian control.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Secretary of State Byrnes declared today that this Government stood firmly on the Berlin protocol governing reparations from Germany, was not departing one iota from it, and expected everybody else to stand by it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Secretary of State Byrnes gave his full support and that of President Truman today to Spruille Braden, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of American Republic Affairs.

The abolition of local price control boards and reduction of the staff of the Office of Price Administration will mean the dropping of 700 paid workers and 9,040 volunteer aides in this five-state region, according to James L. Meader, regional OPA head.

Governor Dewey called upon the voters of the State last night to administer a stinging rebuke to the State Democratic leadership and its candidates for their failure to repudiate Henry Wallace's "Two Worlds" speech or the Moscow endorsement of their ticket.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase in reviewing the 1945-46 academic year at New York University touches, naturally, on both war and peace. His accounting of the university's services to the nation in its emergency is impressive: more than 30,000 graduates and students served with the armed forces ...

In one of the most impressive rallies in recent years, the stock market snapped back sharply yesterday, climbing 2 to 7 points in individual issues while the composite rate rose almost 4 points. Stop-loss orders of the preceding session having been cleared up, the list presented an easy opportunity ...
LONDON, Oct. 31--The House of Commons approved tonight the Government's white paper on the "central organization of defense," which creates a new Ministry of Defense under A.V. Alexander.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Eugene Meyer, president of the World Bank, announced today the filling of the last vacant post of importance on the new institution's staff, but indicated that there would be no haste in the starting of lending operations.

The National Duck Callers Contest is scheduled for Nov. 23 this year, and as in former years it will be held at Stuttgart, Ark., where the mallards are big and plentiful and the rice grows high and lush.
THERE is something fascinating about any new endeavor in sports, particularly when the success of the venture is virtually ordained from the start.

Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in Auto Accident Court caustically commented yesterday on the practice of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau in granting driver's licenses to motorists afflicted with diabetes or heart disease and criticized their failure to check up on such drivers and revoke their licenses.

DETROIT, Oct. 31--The Ford Motor Company and Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations remained generally quiet today, regarding the prospect of a strike against the concern which may begin on Nov. 29.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Leo Durocher, manager of the Dodgers, came here today for a meeting with Prsident Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn club, but refused to disclose whether he had signed a new contract, why the meeting had been held, or even where.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31--Candidates of both major parties tonight alternately praised and condemned the present national Administration at rallies in different parts of New Jersey, as the political campaign entered its final days.

LONDON, Oct. 31--The United States Government's action in refusing to continue the procurement of food for export to Great Britain and in refusing to support Sir John Boyd Orr's plan for world food price stabilization has aroused bitter anti-American outbursts here.
Tomorrow evening's scheduled premiere of "Park Avenue" at the Shubert has been postponed until Monday night because Leonora Corbett, co-star of the musical, is ill with laryngitis.

The possibility of a strike of 24,000 Consolidated Edison Company, employes on Jan. 1 was raised yesterday when the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes, CIO, sent to the company a formal sixty-day notice of the termination of its contract.

Meryll Frost, former captain of the Dartmouth football team and now coaching the jayvees at Hanover, yesterday received the Brotherhood Award for outstanding sportsmanship, at a joint luncheon of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood and the Touchdown Club, held in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31-- Princeton's Orange and Black fits right into the Hallowe'en color motif and Pennsylvania's power house is a haunting specter, in the football sense.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October fell off sharply from the previous month and the corresponding month a year ago. Sales were above the million-share mark in only eleven sessions, the largest of which was 2,374,370 shares on Oct. 15.
The elusive 15-year-old Robert Cronin, the head of a youthful gang of upper West Side hoodlums and self-proclaimed "cop hater," is at large again. The police reluctantly admitted that fact yesterday.

American, French and one English designer united forces in the showing of gala fashions presented by Macy's Little Shop yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The collection included originals by Balmain, Digby Morton, Gres, Madeleine Vramant, Patou, Schiaparelli, Lelong and Balenciaga.
This port continued yesterday its slow progress toward normal operation, with mountains of delayed cargo once more on the move.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The closing of local price-control boards for five years familiar guardians of a wartime economy in thousands of communities, was ordered today by Paul A. Porter, price administrator, because of the tide of decontrol.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Washington's hotel strike ended today on terms which the union hailed as "a complete victory on its main objectives."

The Long Island Rail Road will provide new double-deck passenger cars and hopes to reduce the number of cars laid up for repairs in order to provide more seating accommodations for commuters, John C. White, a vice president, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

Samuel Reshevsky of Boston defeated Dr. G.L. Drexel of Miami in the sixth round of the championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Chanin Auditorium last night and retained the lead with a score of 5--1. In second place is Israel A. Horowitz of New York who triumphed over the champion, Arnold S. Denker, in thirty-nine moves.
The Ballet Theatre last night gave the first performance in its Broadway Theatre season to David Lichine's "Helen of Troy," with Igor Youskevitch for the first time in the role of Paris.

Laying aside the purple for the moment, Helen Haves is appearing in a delightful, sentimental comedy, "Happy Birthday," which was put on at the Broadhurst last evening. Anita Loos, one-time author of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," has written this humoresque in a Newark beer joint.
Cotton futures prices soared yesterday in same cases the permissible daily limit of $10 a bale when trading was resumed on the country's major markets after a one-day suspension.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 (U.P.)-- President Juan D. Peron issued today a decree abolishing the prohibition against foreign news services' supplying Argentine news to Argentine radio stations.
With the consent of all the major powers, the Spanish controversy finally was handed over to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday for full-dress debate.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP)-- Armour Co., Chicago meat packing concern, was found guilty by Judge Guy K. Bard in Federal court today on seventeen counts of an indictment charging that it forced customers to take unwanted commodities to obtain such scarce items as meat and butter.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 31 --William J. McGeory of 248 Grassy Sprain Road, Yonkers, president of the Westchester County Building Construction Trades Council, died here today at the age of 64.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 31--Racial tension in a district of Atlanta today spurred police into a full-scale investigation of recent outrages and of activities of Columbians, Inc., a recently chartered pro-white organization, said to have dedicated itself to aims and principles similar to those of the Ku Klux Klan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The railroads joined issue with the water carriers today in the second day of argument before the Interstate Commerce Commission in which the water carriers are asking the ICC to investigate all water competitive railway rates, with they railroads opposing that action.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 31--Violence again broke out at the West Allis plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company this afternoon as 1,000 members of the striking United Auto Workers, Local 248, CIO, and of other CIO organizations threw a mass picket line before Gate 7.
Accessories played an important role in staging "Fashions of The Times" as was evidenced by a wide variety of shoes, bags, gloves, umbrellas and jewelry worn by the models.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Charges of Yugoslav misuse of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration funds were denied today by the three-man investigating committee sent to that country by F.H. La Guardia, the Director General.

The United Parents Associations announced yesterday that it was "greatly concerned" over Superintendent of Schools John E. Wades repudiation of a circular advising consumers to "refrain from buying" at inflated prices.

Warren B. Ashmead, Jamaica banker and Republican chairman of Queens since 1930, is planning to retire as a political leader soon after next Tuesday's election, according to members of the Republican executive committee of Queens.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP)-- Attacks against non-profit cooperatives as "tax dodgers" were declared unwarranted today by the general manager of the Cooperative Grange League Federation Exchange.

LEWISBURG, Tenn., Oct. 31-- The industrial transition from war to peace here is best typified by the adaption of a factory which made magnesium castings for superchargers to the production of cook-stoves.

Clarence (Pug) Manders, the versatile veteran of seven yeyars' service in the professional football wars, will play a new role in Sunday's game at the Yankee Stadium between the Yankees and the Miami Seahawks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31-- California's legal campaign to take title to lands operated by aliens ineligible to citizenship but held in the names of their American-born children went forward today with a State Supreme Court decision upholding once more the validity of the State's alien-land law.

There will be no immediate advances in shoe prices to the public, and when they are necessary at some later date they will be far below the ideas given by Office of Price Administration officials, according to retailers yesterday Widespread resentment was expressed ...

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 31 (AP)--A military court of ten United States Army colonels convicted Major David F. Watson today of conspiracy and receiving stolen property in the $1,500,000 Hesse family jewel theft and sentenced him to three years' imprisonment and dismissal from the Army.

Philip J. Noel-Baker, British Secretary of State for Air, criticized yesterday as "unsubstantiated allegations" Albania's complaint to the United Nations that British warships in Albanian waters had threatened international peace.
Sportswear, both active and spectator, whirled merrily across the stage in this week's showings of "Fashions of the Times, Fifth Edition."

DOVER, N.J., Oct. 31--The major part of the Government's rocket research and development will be carried on among North Jersey's Hills, Brig. Gen. H.H. Saylor, chief of the Ordnance Department's Research and Development Division, indicated yesterday following a tour of Picatinny Arsenal with a staff of experts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--A tripartite commission of representatives from the world food, trade and fiscal organizations will determine the shape of any international food program that may come out of the present exploratory conference, it was disclosed today.

A program of French music, admirably put together and interpreted with exceptional warmth and brilliancy, was Dr. Rodzinski's present to his Philharmonic-Symphony audience last night in Carnegie Hall.
Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that Governor Dewey should be persuaded to "dump a Fascist following that is a disgrace to the party founded by Abraham Lincoln."

Another scarce item will begin appearing in profusion on grocers' shelves Monday when 185 National Biscuit Company trucks resume deliveries of cookies, crackers and breakfast food for the first time since Sept. 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31-- The principal casting of Argosy Pictures' "The Fugitive" has been completed and filming will begin on location in Mexico on Dec. 1, with John Ford directing, it was learned today.

Municipal bond men say that the tax-exempt market is now facing with equanimity whatever threat of swollen investment supply may be developed by the voting next week on more than a billion dollars in local government bond issues. In the market break which hit bottom ...

The United Nations' General Assembly will consider the Danish delegation's proposal for equal rights for men and women and refer it for action to the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee, it was decided yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Senator Theodore G. Bilbo will face hearings concerning his relations with war contractors before he is due to take his seat for a third term, Francis D. Flanagan, acting chief counsel to the War Investigating Committee, said today.
Most of the riders and all of the horses that will compete for the United States in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show next week arrived yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Average primary market prices increased 0.6 per cent in the week ended Oct. 26, chiefly because of higher prices for livestock that had been removed from OPA control in the previous week. There was a sharp break in cotton quotations from twenty-year highs.
In a time of many problems and distractions we must not forget old friends who are carrying on as always and have their just demands on our atten tion and help.

Borrowings from the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System on a varied assortment of commodities accounted last week for an increase of $45,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, bringing the total for the week ended on Wednesday to a new high of $3,619,000,000, ac- ...

Winning his postponed game from the first round from Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, Isaac I. Kashdan made a place for himself in the first division of the United States chess championship tourney at the Chanin Auditorium last night.

A charge that the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers had made changes in baseball contracts in order to counteract the activity of the Baseball Guild was made at the second conference between representatives of the clubs and the ...
Howard Coonley, chairman of the executive committee of the American Standards Association, has been elected president of the new International Organization for Standardization, formation of ...
LONG MEADOW, Mass., Nov. 1 (U.P.)--Joseph Berg Esenwein, author of many books and critical summaries and editor of Writers Monthly, died at his home here today after a brief illness. His age was 79.

While following three men who had held up his liquor store, Arthur Match, 44 years old, of 80-59 189th Street, Jamaica, Queens, was shot fatally at 7:10 o'clock last night at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1--As a result of the rejection of William A. McClain, a Negro lawyer, for membership in the Cincinnati Bar Association, an effort is being made to modify the admission requirement for an 80 per cent affirmative vote.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1-- Ray Milland was named today as the probable leading player in Hal Wallis' first English production for Paramount "For Her to See," ...

A bitter attack on Representative Vito Marcantonio for "jeopardizing our country by following the Communist party line" was made yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 1 --President Truman came home to Missouri today to vote and cast aside every temptation to say a single political word publicly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The formula proposed by the Civil Aeronautics Administration to govern its allotments of funds under the Federal Airport Act was approved at today's concluding hearing on the draft regulations.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 1 (AP)--J.L. McKnight's Blenweed, racing on the outside in the stretch today, won the Salem Purse at Rockingham Park.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1--While representatives of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, in a series of meetings across the country, have been trying to crystallize ...

The District Attorney's office of Kings County took steps yesterday to return W. Arthur Nickel, 46-year-old cashier of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, to answer to the charge that he embezzled "close to a million dollars" of the company's funds.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 1 --United Nations activity meshed smoothly into gear today after an easy transition from Flushing Meadow, where the opening General Assembly sessions closed yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 1--A new and unusual type of glider which gets its lift from two unpowered free-swinging rotor blades rather than from fixed wings was announced here today by the General Electric Flight Test Center.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 1 --The sixty-ninth annual meeting of the American Bar Association ended here today.

Evidently the warm weather has stimulated mushroom growth, for shipments have been so large and numerous this week that prices are lower than they have been in years, according to Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon,...
Shipping activity reminiscent of pre-war days made the upper New York waterfront a busy scene yesterday as three large passenger liners sailed and a fourth arrived within less than two hours.
Leonard Moser has been appointed assistant vice president and manager of the sales department of Paul P. Zinner, Inc.

If City College Coach Red Gebhard, who ignored the rules of coaching procedure last week and upset Wagner College for the Beavers' first victory in twentyfour starts, is planning the same tactics against Brooklyn College at Ebbets Field tonight, he had better watch out for a boomerang.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Maritime Commission authorized its Pacific Coast agents today to put into effect terms and conditions equal to those which settled the East and Gulf Coast strikes last week.

William A. McClain is the Assistant City Solicitor of Cincinnati, a responsible law post in that beautiful Ohio city of hills; he is a man of good character, a veteran of three years' service in the Army Air Force, a graduate of ...

The playing heard from Frank Sheridan, pianist, at his recital last night in Town Hall, was as spontaneous and individual as it was firmly controlled and sane. All of his performances displayed unerring taste, a keen sense of proportion and a sure grasp of style.
Congratulatory telegrams kept rolling in yesterday as the fifth edition of "Fashions of the Times," THE NEW YORK TIMES annual style show, closed its triumphant four-day performance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 1 --Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, United States delegate; today seconded the proposal of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Russian Vice Foreign Minister, than the United Nations General Assembly study the refugee problem without delay.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 1 (AP)--Control in New Hampshire's largest newspaper, The Manchester Union-Leader, today passed to William Loeb, Vermont publisher, in association with Bernard H. Ridder, Victor F. Ridden and Joseph E. Ridder, brothers.

The steady fall of retail meat prices finally began to bear results yesterday. With steaks and roasts selling in some shops for little more than former ceilings, increased consumer demand was reported for the first time since the decontrol of meat Oct. 15.

To the lilting rhythms of the rhumba, gowns designed for tropical nights swayed across the stage against a background that was reminiscent of Rio's harbor, in one scene of Fashions of the Times, which closed last night.

A Harlem blockfront passed to new control yesterday with the sale by the Eldicon Corporation of the entire west side of Lenox Avenue, from 124th to 125th Street, to the Juneglory Realty Corporation for investment.

Prospects for a settlement of the seven-week-old United Parcel Service strike, possibly today, were considered excellent last night. The outlook brightened after a new series of discussions at City Hall...

J. Archer Turner, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the Turner Construction Company, one of the world's largest building concerns, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.

With a renewal of its pleas that the city transit system be placed on a self-sustaining basis, the City Planning Commission adopted yesterday and sent to the Board of Estimate for approval a proposed capital budget for 1947 of $239,629,204.18.

With two victories and a tie to their credit in the five National Hockey League games they have played to date, the New York Rangers will seek to present the home fans with a victory when they tackle the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 1--Growing concern over the economic revival of Japan and the extent of the rapprochement between Japan and the United States is one of the most pronounced trends in China.
No one would give a nickel for the chances of West Virginia and Navy today against Army and Notre Dame.

TOKYO, Nov. 1--Demands that Japan establish something approximating the United States National Labor Relations Board are reaching a clamorous volume, Keinosuke Zen, chief of the Economic Stabilization Board, said in an interview.
One of the most successful figures in radio also proved last night to be an art collector of some caliber.
"B.F.'s Daughter," by John P. Marquand, which will be published by Little, Brown on Monday, has gone into its fifth printing, totaling 875,000 copies, including the Literary Guild printing.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 1--Twenty-one barracks-type buildings containing sixty-one apartments for veterans were opened here today by officials of New Rochelle and the Federal Public Housing Authority. The structures are on the former soccer field of City Park.
TORONTO, Nov. 1 (AP)--A pair of field goals by Dick Murphy and a free throw by Tommy Byrnes in the final 2 minutes enabled the New York Knickerbockers to nose out the Toronto Huskies, 68--66, ...

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 1 --Senator Pedro C. Hernaez of the Philippine Republic was elected vice chairman of the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today. The committee is faced with debate on Europe's reconstruction and food needs.
Rapid completion of financial arrangements for Long Island's first low-rent, State-aided housing development was reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1--Strength in cotton futures imparted a firm undertone today to grain futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade, but while wheat rose to ...
ARMY vs. West Virginia--Red Blaik is so terrified by the Mountaineers that he and the rest of his coaching staff are running away from them.

BOSTON, Nov. 1--Edmund J. Brandon, United States Attorney for the Massachusetts District since 1939, died late last night at the wheel of his automobile as he was driving his wife to their Chestnut Hill home after attending a Boston theatre.

The United States Lines yesterday extended its North River waterfront holdings when the company took possession of Pier 74, North River, at Thirty--fourth Street, at an annual rental of approximately $63,000.

The resignation of James Johnson Sweeney as director of the Department of Painting and Sculpture of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, was announced yesterday "with regret" on behalf of the board of trustees by Nelson A. Rockefeller, museum president.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 1--All that Robert J. Kleberg's triple-crown winner, Assault, needed was Eddie Arcaro on his back to reshow him the way to go home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Administration declined today to endorse Federal aid to education on the scale proposed by the Murray-Morse-Pepper bill introduced in the last Congress.

Tony Pellone really won one last night The Greenwich Village welterweight registered a triumph over Johnny Greco, Montreal campaigner, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden, and everybody in the crowd, for once, seemed to be in agreement with the award.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1-- Four men, representing the Congress party and the Moslem League in the Interim Government, will visit Calcutta tomorrow and Sunday for a first hand study of Hindu-Moslem tension there, it was learned tonight.
Simple ceremonies at La Guardia Field marked the departure yesterday of the first commercial airliner to carry international air mail at the new reduced postage rates.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1--A worldwide financial clearing house for airlines to handle all intercompany transactions on a sterling and dollar basis has been created by the International Air Transport Association at its second annual meeting here, it was learned today.

UNION, N.J., Nov. 1--Johnny Kinder of the Plainfield G.C., inspired by his appointment as new tournament chairman of the New Jersey P.G.A., walked off with honors in the best-ball pro-woman tournament played over the Suburban Golf Club course today.

BERLIN, Nov. 1--A marked rise in the birthrate among Jewish wards in the displaced persons centers in the American zone of occupation in Germany is one of the major changes noted by Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, ...
Representative Vito Marcantonio and Frederick v.P. Bryan, opponents in the bitter contest in the Eighteenth Congressional District, finally debated the issues last night.
PARIS, Nov. 1--Charles de Gazelle called on the French today to vote on Nov. 10 for Parliamentary candidates who favored rapid revision of the Constitution adopted at the referendum Oct. 13.
Another substantial gap in the recovery effort by the stock market was closed yesterday as bidding was well maintained in the industrial shares with additional support supplied by the railway issues.

Work on a dozen pending Broadway theatrical productions was suspended yesterday as 300 members of Scenic Artists Local 829 laid down their tools to await a report on contract negotiations with the Theatrical Contractors Association.
Columbia and Cornell will meet before a capacity crowd of 35,000 at Baker Field today in the thirtyfourth game of a colorful Ivy League rivalry dating back to 1889.
With practically all foods removed from price control, OPA is now announcing almost daily long lists of nonfood products from which ceilings are being removed.

Parke, Davis Co. and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year net profit, after taxes and other charges, of $9,352,620, equal to $1.91 a share. For the nine months ended with September, 1945, the net profit was $5,701,462, or $1.16 a share.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The roster of articles and products removed from price control today by the Office of Price Administration ranged from farm machinery and other equipment to textile notions, wood and paper matches and paper diapers.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Nov. 1 (AP)--South Carolina's Gamecocks defeated The Citadel today by 19--7 to complete their conquest of all the State's other Southern Conference teams and to earn a claim to the South Carolina college football championship.

LONDON, Nov. 1--Fighting broke out in a London church today when persons in the congre gation protested against the presence of Dr. J.W.C. Wand, Anglican Bishop of London, and against the celebration of high mass.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Renewed attempts to mediate the seven-month-old strike at the Allis Chalmers plant in West Allis, Wis., will be undertaken in Washington if the disputants accept the Government's invitation.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 1-Predictions of a sweeping Republican victory for party candidates in New Jersey and a charge that the Democrats were attempting to "buy" the election next Tuesday were made by Republican leaders today.

Former Detective Jacob von Weisenstein of the Missing Persons Bureau of the New York City Police, who achieved some note through his successful work on puzzling cases, died on Wednesday in Rockaway Beach Hospital, Rockaway Beach, Queens. PARIS, Nov. 7--Molyneux, in his mid-season collection of thirty models, casts aside circular fullness. The flare, if any, is moderate, most models being pencil slim.

TOKYO, Nov. 7--Attacks upon Tanzan Ishibashi, Japan's Minister of Finance, have reached a point where they threaten to bring about a headlong flight from the yen, a development that would interfere seriously with the occupation objectives.

LONDON, Nov. 7--A bout of profit-taking following the sharp overnight fall on Wall Street weakened the stock markets here today. The setback came as a disappointment, as an improvement had been expected after the results of the elections in the United States.

Christmas liquor prices will be down, not up, on all items except bottled-in-bonds, Bourbon and Scotch, retail liquor store owners predicted yesterday. Even aged whiskies and Scotch might slide lower, they said, as retailers loosen up on stocks and consumer resistance makes itself felt.

Members of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, will learn at their Sabbath eve workship at 5:30 P.M. today that their building has been freed of debt for the first time since it was erected seventeen years ago. The total debt was $1,250,000.

A $200,000 contract was signed yesterday through the medium of television by representatives of the Chevrolet division, General Motors Corporation, in Washington and Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president of Du Mont Laboratories here.

An American heroine who rescued 300 girls in China from the Japanese embarked yesterday with thirty-two other young men and women on overseas career work for the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Supreme Court affirmed, 6 to 3, today the conviction of six persons on charges that their practice of plural marriage had violated the Mann Act.

The Beach Fortieth Street Corporation has purchased ten bungalows on a plot 100 by 100 feet on Beach Fortieth Street, Edgemere Queens, from the Raymas Realty Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $18,000.

Plans for a 600-family garden apartment rental project at Union Turnpike and Commonwealth Boulevard in Bellerose Hills, Queens, were filed yesterday by the Gross-Morton Company.

"Aida" made its very welcome return to the Metropolitan after an absence of a season last night, and the audience rejoiced greatly. It used to be almost the custom, and not a bad one, to open opera seasons with this work.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18-- Benedict Bogeaus today signed Joan Blondell to play opposite George Brent in the forthcoming episodic picture, "Christmas Eve," which United Artists will release.

Upper Broadway will enter a new phase next month, when, for the first time in more than half a century, street cars will disappear from that area. The street cars will be succeeded by buses on Dec. 1, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation announced yesterday.

The Metropolitan Museum will open to the public today its newlyinstalled Oriental arms and armor collection. The bulk of the material had not been on view for several years, and some of the pieces have not been previously shown at all. It is described as the first comprehensive installation.

Rokossovsky, Soviet commander in Poland, and Polish Marshal Michal Rola-Zymieiski have signed an agreement calling for a reduction of the number of Soviet Army troops in Poland, it was learned today.

For those New Yorkers who are planning to stock their Thanksgiving larders with turkey, chicken or duck the word from local Government agencies and Long Island poultry farms yesterday was that fowl would be plentiful and would cost only slightly more than when under price control.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday on motion by Mayor O'Dwyer a resolution authorizing the payment of $14,135 to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx as reimbursement for salary lost during the period from March 22.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The Manhattan Project's current research work in the conversion of atomic energy to peacetime uses is concentrated on the problem of adapting present power-producing techniques and equipment to the new type of fuel, it was officially reported today.

BERLIN, Nov. 21--The conversion of German marks into new currency is "out of the question" for several months, S.P. Chambers, chief of the finance division of the British element of the military government, revealed today.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 (AP)--Harrison Elliott's Dixie Sweep and Apprentice Willie Barr teamed to win the Hambleton Purse today.
John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America have been ordered to appear in Federal Court Monday to show cause why they should not be held in contempt for not having called...

The City Planning Commission's proposed 1947 capital budget of $239,629,204 had only a few supporters yesterday among the sixty speakers heard by Mayor O'Dwyer and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate at a public hearing that lasted almost six hours.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 21--Secrecy and mystery continued to surround the special Senate investigation into alleged associations, in 1942, between Senator Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi and war contractors, as the inquiry went into its second phase today.
The State's fifth and sixth temporary housing projects in the city have reached the stage where 129 veterans will start moving in, it was announced yesterday.

Assailing present-day liberal arts colleges as inadequate and inflexible, Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens College, called on those institutions last night to undergo a "heroic" reorganization to provide "for the great variety of interests and the wide range of abilities" of their students.

Youngsters and the young in spirit, from 6 to 60, will be treated again this year to the fanciful delights of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade. The twentieth annual revival on Thursday of what has come to be an institution in the city will feature five giant heliuminflated balloons, sixteen colored floats and six bands.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.)-- The Department of Commerce said today that all employes of the Inland Waterways Corporation who went on strike during election week would be discharged.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 21 --Over Soviet opposition, a resolution authorizing Secretary General Trygve Lie to explore the problems involved in setting up a common budget for the United Nations, including all specialized agencies, was approved today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

A charge that the shooting early yesterday of an adviser to the Ukrainian delegation to the United Nations during a delicatessen store hold-up was "political banditry" was denied later by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.
Tanners and shoe manufacturers are beginning to discern a trend toward a stabilized and eased price pattern in the hide market.

New York paid its final tribute yesterday to former Mayor James J. Walker, St. Patrick's Cathedral was filled to capacity and 10,000 persons crowded street corners in the vicinity as the funeral service was held, starting at 10:25 A.M.

Two arraignments in a drive on the so-called "52-20 Club," that is, veterans who draw $20 a week up to a year in unemployment compensation while holding jobs on the side, were chalked up yesterday by the State Department of Labor starting its campaign against such frauds.

In his account of the various places, other than "ex-enemy states," from which Russian troops have been withdrawn, Mr. Molotov omitted on Wednesday mention of three areas of considerable importance.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, has been appointed to succeed the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick on the weekly "National Vespers" radio program, it was announced yesterday.

Fourteen singers who were members of the Metropolitan Opera Association last year have not been re-engaged for this season, it was disclosed yesterday when the season's roster was made public by the management.

AS the football season moves on apace there is one department of play in which the disparity between the collegians and the professionals becomes all the more striking. It's nothing new, of course, but about this time of year it always becomes more and more obvious.

A study of truancy, leading to a new unified approach to its solutibn by public and private agencies, will be one of the projects undertaken by the Community Service Society, through its newly established Bureau of Public Affairs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 21 --Great Britain placed before a United Nations Trusteeship Subcommittee today a proposal aimed at deferring any decision on the need for a new special committee to deal with informative reports on non-self-governing territories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Completion of the first section of a Guaranteed Wage Study was announced today by George W. Taylor, chairman of the advisory board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP)-- Army and Notre Dame may play off their recent scoreless tie in a charity football game in Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Dec. 22 or 25.

William May, 28 years old, a minor official of local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, was shot and killed shortly before midnight Wednesday in a bar and grill at 322 Henry Street, the police disclosed yesterday.

Retail lumbermen throughout the nation have launched a drive for termination of priorities regulations "and all other obstacles to a free market," Fred, W. Ritter, secretary of the New York Lumber Trades Association, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Two New York City hotels announce that they have converted their heating plants from coal to oil and need not therefore be "bothered" any more by the "interruption" of coal strikes.

The property at 1779 Eightyfirst Street, corner of Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, containing six stores and fifty-five apartments on a plot 145 by 100 feet, has been sold by Sidney Levine, Samuel Siegenfeld and others to the Bensonhurst Garden Buildings Corporation. Sale was for cash above mortgages of $135,000. Henry Brinsley was the broker.

It is to be Ken Strong Day at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, when the New York Giants face the Pittsburgh Steelers, but until yesterday there was considerable doubt that the grand old man of the gridiron would be in uniform to receive the honors that will be heaped on him.

Although "In This Very Room" has aroused the interest of several managements, the Harold Goldman comedy is yet to be produced. It won't be long now, though.

Following its 1-cent increase in price of last week, butter has gone up again, according to the City Department of Markets, and consumers doing their pre-Sunday marketing will find it ranging from 83 cents to $1 a pound, with a general average of 95 cents. LONDON, NOV. 21--The British Foreign Office published today the texts of the two notes sent to Soviet Government Aug. 21 and Oct. 9, rejecting Russian proposals regarding the Dardanelles and the future of the Montreux Convention.
Eduardo Marquina, Spanish playwright and poet, who was president of the Society of Authors of Spain, died yesterday of a heart attack in his suite at the Hotel Roosevelt. His age was 67.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Load ings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 16 were 917,124 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21--The standard of American motion pictures is declining rapidly because of the star system, the lack of realism and the shortage of "progressive" directors, according to Serge A. Gerasimov, one of the Soviet Union's leading film producers.

Life insurance leaders were warned yesterday by Robert E. Dineen, New York State Superintendent of Insurance, that if the States fail to institute rate regulatory laws deemed by Congress adequate to protect the public interest, the alternative may be Federal regulation of the entire business.

Directors of the Glenn L. Martin Company, aircraft manufacturer, declared yesterday in Baltimore, Md., a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock and elected Robert H. Kittner as vice president in charge of the plastics and chemicals division, a newly created office.

BRAMANS, France, Nov. 21 --A faint and perhaps final radio message came today from the wreck of an Army C-53 transport that crashed with eleven Americans aboard in the freezing Alps along the French-Italian border last Tuesday. It said: "Must have aid today to survive. In deep snow on south side of slope facing east."

The building containing six stores and twenty-one apartments at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street has been sold by the E.J. Realty Corporation to an investing client of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., the brokers in the transaction.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 21--John M. Greenwood, general safety agent for the New York Central System, was found dead, apparently from a heart attack, late yesterday in a Pullman berth at Union Station here. His age was 59.

The first undergraduate medical school in Palestine will be built under the joint auspices of the Hebrew University and Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America, Dr. Eli Davis, deputy medical director of Hadassah in Jerusalem, announced yesterday.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" was restored to the Metropolitan repertory last night after a lapse of three years and the performance under the direction of Emil Cooper was the best we have seen of the work in this theatre.
Artur Rodzinski conducted the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night in a program of Russian music that seemed to please the large audience.

Increased tire life of at least 15 per cent, fewer blowouts and easier car steering, provided the new wider base rims for automobiles, trucks and buses are utilized, were forecast last night at a meeting of the metropolitan section of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP)-- The Bell XS-1, this country's first supersonic aircraft, said to be the sturdiest plane ever built, will make its first powered flight at Muroc Army air field, Calif., probably between Dec. 1 and 15, the Army Air Forces revealed tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 21--The possibility that the London conference on Palestine, adjourned on Oct. 2 until Dec. 16, will not be resumed until after the New Year was accepted as a fact in informed circles here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Urgent appeals for the immediate recall of Congress by President Truman for action now on labor measures arose in bi-partisan chorus at the Capitol today as the coal situation moved toward a court showdown.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21--Canadian pulp producers "have not taken and do not seek the inflated and at times fantastic prices reported in some overseas markets," the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association said in a statement today.

A hot and cold Syracuse team, anxious to fulfill its coach's preseason prediction that the Orange would win five of its nine games this year, will arrive here at 3 o'clock this afternoon and proceed to Baker Field for an hour's drill, the final preparation before trying to nail down that fifth victory tomorrow against Columbia.

The Council on Dental Education of the American Dental Association has sent a letter to the dean of every dental school in the country stating its unequivocal opposition to the establishment of quotas for admission based on religion or race, it was learned yesterday.

Edward C. Blum, chairman of the board of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, died Wednesday in his apartment in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, at the age of 83. He was a former president of the Art Commission of the City of New York and a former vice chairman of the New York State Probation Commission.

Premier Constantin Tsaldaris of Greece is coming to New York next week to charge before the United Nations persistent violations of the Grecian frontier from the north and to demand some sort of examination of the situation, it was learned yesterday.
Francis E. Walton of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of his daughter, Francise, to Thomas D. Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cord Meyer of 14 East Sixty-third Street.

Schedules of drastic reductions in interurban and main-line passenger service were released yesterday by the nation's railroads in response to the first major soft coal conservation measure ordered by the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Any prolongation of the coal strike promised today to force Government action in several fields.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21--The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated nervously today, and trading was restricted by the coal strike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today increased express rates on general commodities between sixty-one points in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania.

A group of one-story garages and a factory building at 200. Veronica Place, in Brooklyn, were sold by the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation to Eugene H. Tinsley, who will occup for his fuel oil business. The Premier Realty Company was the broker.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 24--The greyhound Ch. Magic of Mardormere won best-in-show for the second day in a row for a perfect dog show week-end in the fifteenth event of the Camden County Kennel Club today.

Operation of the radio station WHOM under the ownership of Generoso Pope was begun yesterday with a special concert and program at the Hotel Biltmore before an invited audience of public officials and persons prominent in Italian circles. The program was followed by a reception and dinner.
Music of Shostakovich and Dvorak made up the program of the season's fourth concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon.

Clarence Benjamin Heiserman of Haverford, Pa., retired vice president and general counsel of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died Saturday in the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital, after an illness of several weeks, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 84.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 24-- The economic and statistical department of the National Bank of Switzerland issued last week its annual report giving an exhaustive analysis of the development of banking in Switzerland during the transition year 1945.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP)--Pouring in four goals in the last period, two by Right Wing Howie Meeker, the Toronto Maple Leafs hung on to their National Hockey League lead tonight, blanking the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 0, before 14,619 fans-- largest crowd ever to see a regular league game here.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 24-- Out in a southwest wind went twenty-one of the new coldweather sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, and it turned into a real hard-weather test.

SWEDEN, Nov. 24--Swedish wood-pulp and paper manufacturers are already solidly booked for their 1947 production but the mills still have certain quantities available that are hold-outs from this year's output.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--The Federal Finance Committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce proposed today a 25 per cent reduction in individual income taxes, and a progressively sharp decrease in taxes on corporate incomes.

The Giants lived up to their reputation yesterday when they beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 7 to 0, in a rock-sock game attended by 45,347 at the Polo Grounds, and enhanced their chances of winning the Eastern championship in the National Football League.

The Council of Foreign Ministers will enter its fourth week of trying to write the peace when it reconvenes at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 4 P. M. today.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 24--A bloody, fratricidal war is being waged between the Government and the underground in Poland. It probably will take 7,000 or more lives this year and there is no end to it in sight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24--Shots were exchanged between the Egyptian police and university students today when many hundreds of nationalist students again attempted a sortie into Cairo's main streets for an anti-Government and anti-British demonstration.
The forthcoming observance of Thanksgiving was the theme of a number of sermons yesterday by clergymen in churches throughout the city.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP)--Running wild in each period, the Boston Yanks gained their first victory in nine National Football League starts by humbling the championship Los Angeles Rams, 40--21, today at Fenway Park. Sonny Karnofsky sent the green-jerseyed victors off to a flying start by returning the opening kick-off 97 yards for a touchdown.

In another one of those fraudulent elections which are establishing a common pattern for the Russian-dominated Balkans, the Rumanian Government bloc controlled by the Communists has voted itself a thumping majority of more than two-thirds of the vote cast and an almost 85 per cent majority in the Parliament.
The Citizens Housing Council of New York urged President Truman yesterday to "hold fast to remaining controls on housing construction to retain any possibility of supplying homes to our veterans."

GILLESPIE, Ill., Nov. 24 (U.P.)-- A meeting of Progressive Mine Workers members who struck in sympathy with the United Mine Workers walkout, voted 208 to 52 late today to return to work, but failure of 540 other members to vote left the status of the PMW walkout in doubt.

MEIRINGEN, Switzerland, Nov. 24--Two daring Swiss pilots, making nine shuttle trips in ski-equipped planes, today plucked a dozen hungry but happy Americans off the Alpine glacier where they had rationed chocolate bars and drunk snow water. They had been marooned five days.

Introduction of the principle of stretching red-hot steel longer and thinner while it is being rolled will be a major innovation when the National Tube Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, sets up in the near future the world's first continuous seamless tube mill at its plant in Lorain, Ohio.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24--Cash wheat and wheat futures sold last week at a new twenty-six-year high price on the Board of Trade, and corn and oats were the highest in about a month as the result of fairly general buying headed by cash interests and shorts.

The restaurateurs of New York, preparing for an unusually heavy Thanksgiving business, are gracing their holiday menus with viands that tvere absent during the greater part of the war years, a check-up showed yesterday.

Buyers of ready-to-wear in the wholesale markets last week continued to exercise caution in purchases while activity in other wholesale markets remained relatively unchanged, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 24-- "Beat Army," boldly painted in bright red and blue letters on they principal monuments of the United States Military Academy, greeted the Corps of Cadets at reveille this morning.

The difficult job of blending light and dark woods in the same piece of furniture and combining burl veneers with complicated marquetry has been achieved without any of the usual garishness in a group of furniture and lamps by Andrew Szoeke, which go on exhibit at Altman's this morning.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged yesterday that Americans accept a sense of responsibility for the future of displaced persons abroad, not only out of humanitarian ideals but also to aid world economic recovery. Unless such feeling takes root, she warned,

The Maritime Commission will open bids this afternoon for twenty-four vessels. Among those to be sold is a Coast Guard cutter that played an exciting role in foiling German efforts to obtain radio weather information in Greenland during the recent war.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP)--The State Post-War Public Works Planning Commission announced today the approval of an $84,100 advance from the post-war reconstruction fund for planning dormitories at eleven State teachers colleges. CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP)--The Chicago Bears smashed the Detroit Lions by 42 to 6 today to clinch their eighth Western Division National Football League championship after the Los Angeles Rams and Green Bay Packers had been knocked out of contention by upsets in other games.

The news that more than 52 per cent of the country's 6,437,000 farms now have electricity is an encouraging sign of a new era in rural areas. In a nation approximately 80 per cent urban it has been easy to overlook the fact that farms have lagged far behind cities and towns in the comforts of living that city dwellers take for granted.

ATHENS, Nov. 24(AP)--Premier Constantin Tsaldaris conferred today with King George II but said he did not "know when, where and if" a Greek complaint of border violations would be lodged with the United Nations.

STUTTGART, Germany, Monday, Nov. 25 (AP)--Virtually complete returns showed today that voters of the State of Wuerttemberg-Baden in the United States occupation zone had approved by a 7-to-1 ratio their first democratic Constitution and accompanying bill of rights since Adolf Hitler seized power thirteen years ago.

Cartels and inter-governmental commodity agreements were branded over the week-end by the National Association of Manufacturers as instruments of "monopolistic exploitation" of the consumer for the "sole benefit" of the producer.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 24--The Colorado--or democratic --party was leading the ultranationalist Herreristas by more than two to one in early returns in today's national elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)-- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio is "somewhat inclined" to take the chairmanship of the Senate labor committee and has written Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont to that effect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24--A policy of maintaining the existing rent control structure, with possible minor modifications, and of leaving to the incoming Congress decisions on a drastic overhaul of rental ceilings was reported today in high favor in top Administration circles.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP)-- The Washington Redskins climbed back into the thick of the National Football League eastern division race today, outclassing the Philadelphia Eagles, 27-10, before 36,633 at Shibe Park. The loss, to all practical purposes, eliminated the Eagles from title consideration.
The Brookhattans defeated the New York Americans by 3 to 2 in an American Soccer League fixture at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. The first half was scoreless.

Forty-seven LCT's (Mark V) are for sale at the fixed price of $7,500 each, on an "as is, where is" basis, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission.

Pope Pius XII, in a broadcast from the Vatican commemorating the tercentenary of the Jesuit Martyrs of North America yesterday, urged American youth, "always so eager to throw themselves into every worthy and noble venture," to "seize the torch of faith" and carry it to the ends of the earth.

A funeral service for Edward C. Blum, chairman of the Board of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn Department store, and of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, was held yesterday afternoon in Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. It was conducted by the Rev. Sidney S. Tedesche.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--The railroads charged the Government "lawful rates" fox all-of its wartime shipments, R.V. Fletcher, acting president of the Association of American Railroads, declared today.

BANTAM, Conn., Nov. 25 (AP)-- George Sheppard Chappell, associate editor and columnist of The Litchfield Enquirer, also an architect, author and lecturer, died today in his West Bantam home after a long illness. His age was 69.
"The First Christmas," a beautiful exhibition of medieval illuminated manuscripts and somewhat later drawings, opened yesterday at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--President Truman created today a commission to study the Government's methods for testing the loyalty of its more than 2,000,000 employes.

Several hundred persons in Pennsylvania Station witnessed yesterday morning a ceremony opening the station solicitation appeal of the Travelers Aid Society of New York. It is part of the society's current maintenance appeal for $450,000.

And, as we have remarked more than once in... this column, holidays in these times are the best for walking in New York because so many New Yorkers are somewhere else. LONDON, Dec. 1--The hunt investments to take the place the railway stocks that the Government will take over under the nationalization plan is dying down and the stock markets here generally are quieter and somewhat heavy. Some have managed find alternative investments will give them a better return that the meager yield that will be obtainable on the compensation stock to be handed out by the Government, while others have abandoned the chase temporarily.

PARIS, Dec. 1--On the eve of what promised to be a week of further futile maneuvers, with the Assembly meeting Tuesday to elect its President and the Socialist congress postponed until after this event, the most skilled political observers today foresaw no early...
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP)--Tropical Park will usher in the Florida horse-racing season tomorrow.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1-- Bankers registering for the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association are concerned uppermost about the nation's need for "getting its domestic economy into shape," Charles S. Garland, president of the association, told a press conference at the Biltmore Hotel here today on the eve of the formal convention sessions, which will continue until Friday. More than 800 delegates have registered.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP)--Ab De Marco drove in a short shot in the last four minutes of play tonight to give the New York Rangers a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the hapless Black Hawks. The latter did their utmost to please 16,773 home fans after being trounced, 11--0, by Toronto twenty-four hours earlier.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1--Production of lard is increasing, and although the demand continues active, especially for export, restrictions on the amount that can be sent to the various countries is having the effect of curtailing sales.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 1-- The self-styled anti-Communist group in Local 203, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, lost by a narrow margin today the first round in its campaign to halt Communist activity in the organization. The local is composed of employes of the General Electric Company here.

On British merchantmen on the seven seas they spoke fondly yesterday of the British Apprentice Club in New York and of Mrs. Hollon Spaulding, its resident manager, who for twenty-five years has been mother, confidante and confessor to more than 10,000 cadet officers--the waifs of the merchant marine.

It was simply a case of too much Waterfield at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the backfield wizard of the Los Angeles Rams passed and kicked the 1945 champions of the National Football League to a well-earned triumph over the Giants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (U.P.)-- State legislatures have failed to increase the benefits paid under workmen's compensation laws in line with the rise in wages and the cost-of-living, the Department of Labor reported tonight. The Department will present copies of the report and a survey of State workmen's compensation laws to the thirteenth Annual National Conference on Labor Legislation beginning tomorrow.

SUCHOW, China, Dec. 1-- After having lived with Chinese Communists under an uneasy truce for eighteen months, 57-year-old Msgr. Nicolas Tzarvas, Bishop of Taming, arrived here today at the Roman Catholic mission with a report of abuse at the hands of the Reds.

WARSAW, Poland Dec. 1--The "Democratic bloc," led by the Communists and Socialists, began a campaign this week-end to reassure Poles that the bloc's victory in the elections on Jan. 19 would not result in a Moscowdominated dictatorship.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Monday, Dec. 2--The Christian Social Union won a majority in the Bavarian Landtag while the Social Democrats won a plurality in Greater Hesse as both states adopted constitutions in yesterday's elections. This balloting...

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1 (AP)--Shootto-kill orders were issued to police tonight and the Woosung garrison declared an emergency as shuttered Shanghai strove to choke off bloody rioting, which authorities attributed to the Communists.

Financing for industrial corporations, particularly motor and steel companies, featured the public offerings of new securities here in November. Stock offerings were swelled to the largest total for any November since 1928; bond issues to the biggest figure for the month since 1944.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 1 --Under a new speed-up system a trusteeship subcommittee succeeded tonight in adopting the first four articles of draft agreements for New Guinea and each of the six African mandates under British, French or Belgian control.

British Foreign Secretary Bevin went to the Polo Grounds yesterday for a little fresh air and relaxation from the strain of four consecutive weeks of meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers meetings. Mr. Bevin not only saw a professional football game, he also encountered a minor hostile political demonstration directed against him.

Religion's battle against "practical atheism" can be won not so much by eloquence of argument as by conduct based on religious precepts, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

BERLIN, Dec. 1--Thirteen top representatives of the German iron and steel industry met in a closed session in Duesseldorf Friday on the invitation of the deputy for the British zone on the Bizonal Economic Committee, according to a remarkably caustic article in today's Telegraf, British - licensed Berlin paper.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1--Dr. John M. Whitney, first superintendent of public health for this city when appointed five years ago, said today that "no discussion of illness and disease is complete in New Orleans without recognizing that the number one problem here, is housing."

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 1--The Soviet Union's dominant position in Polish foreign trade has been maintained in the new barter agreement for 1947 signed recently, it was learned today. Russia will continue to get the bulk of this commerce, estimated at 50 to 85 per cent.

The people of Byelorussia (White Russia) want to see "true friendship" among all the nations of the world and the "establishment of international understanding," Kuzma V. Kiselev, Byelorussian Foreign Minister and head of the White Russian delegation to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP)--The Boston Bruins protected their National Hockey League third rung by, coming from behind for a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden. Don Gallinger scored twice for the Bruins and Roy Conacher notched two for the Red Wings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)-- The State Department is considering plans to revamp and expand its "Voice of America" shortwave broadcasts to foreign countries, Government officials disclosed today.
Two youths were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and accused of what Assistant District Attorney Samuel Y. Gitlin characterized as "one of the most vicious attacks in my experience."
The seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, was marked yesterday.
Beth-el Hospital of Brooklyn began last night a campaign for a $2,500,000 building fund to double the present 230-bed capacity of the hospital.
VIENNA. Dec. 1--New York's Metropolitan Opera was ridiculed in a long article appearing in today's New Austria, one of the leading Vienna newspapers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP)--Elliott Roosevelt said tonight that he had not accused the United States Embassy or Embassy officials of being implicated in the publication of an off-the-record discussion he had soon after his arrival here.
With a solemn mass of exposition and a procession, a forty-hour devotion was begun in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the first Sunday of Advent.
LONDON, Dec. 1--Coal is the key to peace in Europe, Herbert S. Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said tonight in an appeal to British miners to increase productivity.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 1--A three-car crash on Route 4 near the Broad Avenue overpass resulted today in the death of five persons and injury to seven others. All the vehicles caught fire and traffic on the highway was rerouted for more than three hours.
Dramatically talented "kids from the sticks" may get their big chance on Broadway under proposals accepted yesterday by the National Theatre Conference.

The National Committee for Labor Palestine ended a two-day convention, here yesterday after bitterly condemning "the irresponsible acts of terrorism" of the Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Stern group in Palestine.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1--The United States contributed at least 300 guests, including a former Ambassador, the widow of another, a Cabinet member and a four-star general to Mexico's inaugural festivities. It lent an impressive formation...

BERLIN, Dec. 1--Because it is confronted with procurement difficulties when dealing with German marks, the United States Army Exchange Service will now spend dollars when buying in the French and Soviet zones. The service's purchases in the American and British zones are to be considered as exports from the German economy and the funds from such sales will now be applied to the dollar pool for essential imports.

One of the most effective remedies for hypertension and worry is religion, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street. He asserted that religion gives relaxation and peace.

The late Porfirio Diaz, who ruled Mexico with an iron hand between 1884 and 1911, would scarcely recognize the republic which yesterday inaugurated 43-year-old Miguel Aleman as its "first clearly civilian President."

ABOUT fifteen miles east of Troy, in the New York foothills of the Taconic and Green Mountains of New England, there is a small town of less than 1,000 population. Its one factory was long since closed; many of its farms have been abandoned; twice as many people lived there eighty years ago. Since this particular...
Last month 1,009,802 sacks of foreign mail, 95 per cent of which comprised parcels of food and clothing, were shipped from New York City, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1 (AP) --Robert F. Giegengack, who developed outstanding runners at Brooklyn Prep and at Fordham, has been appointed track coach at Yale, Bob Kiphuth, athletic director, announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (U.P.)-- President Truman today told municipal attorneys representing 441 cities that "the increasing responsibility of communities in solving their own problems is a situation much to be desired in our nation."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1--The Wafd party, strongest and most vigorous opponents of the present Egyptian Government and the proposed treaty with Britain, will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to meet the Government's latest challenge. Yesterday a ban was...

TOKYO, Dec. 1--A proposal to create a new agency within the United States Government to administer Pacific islands under United Nations trusteeship was made here today by Rep. Ed. V. Izac, Democrat, of California. Mr. Izac is chairman of a House naval affairs subcommittee that is now in Tokyo during a tour of American Pacific bases.
