LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (AP)-- Clash of major and minor league baseball viewpoints at their annual meetings here this week was discounted today by Frank Lane, new president of the American Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 1 --Declaring that because of ineffective selection and placement, labor turnover alone represents a staggering financial loss in many companies, Dr. Richard A. Fear, director of the industrial division, the Psychological Corporation, New York, said today that industry can save millions of dollars yearly through the proper application of psychology in selecting technical personnel.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1--The party en route to a conference in London on India arrived here by plane today from Karachi. It was headed by the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell. With him were Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, vice president of the Executive Council, representing...

MOSCOW, Dec. 1--A comprehensive plan for the reconstruction and improvement of Moscow that places great emphasis on improved living conditions has been announced by G.M. Popov, chairman of the executive committee of the Moscow Soviet.

It is to the honor of the National Broadcasting Company and to the benefit of its far-reaching radio audience that yesterday afternoon Arturo Toscanini could be heard over the air as conductor of the first two acts of Verdi's "Traviata." Mr. Toscanini was assisted by singers of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and he directed the NBC Symphony Orchestra.

Strong protests will be made by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers against any reductions in wool fabric tariffs, it was learned over the week-end. The organization is working on an exhaustive brief which will be filed with the Committee on Reciprocity Information in opposition to further tariff cuts. The brief will express...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The suppressed report of the Senate War Investigating Committee on conditions in the United States occupation zone in Germany charges: Widespread misconduct on the part of United States Army officers and men, notably Negroes;

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. E. Clifford Williams of 280 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Penelope, to Erik C.W.C.M. Reinders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willem F.G.O. Reinders-Van Gulick of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 1 --The United Nations General Assembly made an eleventh-hour attempt today to come to a compromise on the veto problem.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 1--An Irish-bred chestnut gelding, Golden Hill, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., dominated the conformation hunter division of Boulder Brook Club's nineteenth annual indoor fall horse show and won the final stake event tonight to amass 231 points and the championship.

Four firemen were injured, three of them seriously, in a gasoline explosion yesterday in the basement of the four-story Amsterdam Garage, 238-40 West Fifty-fourth Street. The blast occurred shortly after 11 A.M. as the firemen were investigating a gasoline leak from a storage tank.

Because of the long holiday week-end, fewer buyers were in town and purchasing for spring was retarded in the wholesale markets, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Some buyers were expected this week to pick up lastminute purchases for Christmas. Allotments, it was reported, were going out as supplies increased.

This week's offerings of Government surplus goods in the New York area include blimps, flashlight bulbs, used marine chronometers, new binocular cases, and tripod periscopes, it was announced over the week-end by Frank L. Symour, regional director of the War Assets Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)-- Theodore Fritsch, 210-pound Green Bay fullback, scored all his team's points today as the Packers hung a 20-7 National Football League defeat on the Washington Redskins.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1--Edward Gowen Budd, founder and president of the Budd Company of Philadelphia, who was a leader in the development of the welded all steel automobile body, the steel disk wheel and the light-weight stainless-steel train, airplane and boat, died of a heart attack last night at his home in Germantown His age was 75.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 1--Four concessions have been made by Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck to the demands of the Stock Exchange and financial quarters.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP)--A 58-yard touchdown run by Bosh Pritchard and a 15-yard field goal by Augie Lio carried the Philadelphia Eagles to a 10-to-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in a national football league game before a crowd of 29,943.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total since August, the volume of business was the largest--with the exception of last year--since 1938 for a corresponding month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1-- Metro--Goldwyn--Mayer has announced that Judy Garland has signed a new contract with the company and that she will play the lead in "The Good Old Summer Time" after completing "The Pirate," which is scheduled for the cameras in January. Gene Kelly will appear opposite Miss Garland in both films.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP)-- Harry Todd of Dallas, Tex., captured his first major tournament as a professional golfer today when he won the $10,000 Orlando open by the margin of a single stroke.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 1 (AP)-- A gallant Navy football team came home tonight to a victor's welcome, a warm reception that softened the chilling breezes from the Severn River and the sting of defeat by Army.
The Brooklyn Wanderers defeated the Brookhattan F.C., 2 to 1, in an American Soccer League match at Sterling Oval yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP)--A Canadian, A. Kelsey of Erickson, B.C., became "Wheat King of North America" today when his sample of hard red spring type wheat was adjudged the finest at the fortyseventh International Livestock Exposition.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1--Miguel Aleman Valdes became President of the United States of Mexico shortly before noon this morning. Twenty-five hundred persons, including distinguished representatives from more than thirty nations attended the ceremonies in the Palace of Fine Arts.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1(AP)--The Communist party newspaper Pravda expressed concern today about the approaching Parliamentary elections in Iran and charged that the Government of Premier Ahmad Ghavam "either lacks the resolve or is unable to counter the everrising pressure of reactionary circles."
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 1-- Dr. Christopher C. Beling, wellknown psychiatry and neurology specialist, died last night in his home at 102 North Mountain Avenue, after a brief illness. His age was 76.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 1-- Bankers here were notified on Friday that the United States Treasury had released Swiss dollar balances blocked in the United States since June 14, 1941. Official quarters declared that for technical reasons the certification of ownership upon which release of individual holdings depended could not begin before about the middle of January.

The worst emergency in the history of the brake shoe industry has developed from foundry supply shortages of coke, scrap and pig iron, officials of the American Brake Shoe Company revealed here over the week-end. This shortage, worse than their difficulties at the peak of the war production period, threatens further curtailments of rail transportation, they said.

Cartels reached the point just before the war where even in this country they controlled to some measure about 87 per cent of the mineral products, including oil, 60 per cent of the agricultural products and 42 per cent of the manufactured products in international commerce, it is stated in "Cartels in Action;" soon to be released by the Twentieth Century Fund.

Emmett W. Hines has been named manager of the New York zone of the Otis Elevator Company. James A. Irvine has become associated with the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers to establish an industrial relations service department for the use of member mills.

The board of directors of the National Council of Jewish Juniors, auxiliary of the National Council of Jewish Women, voted yesterday to increase participation in the senior group's overseas program. The action was taken at the closing session of a three-day meeting at the Hotel New Yorker, attended by twenty-five members.

The Argentine Government has approved an increase in the authorized capital stock of Swift International Company, Ltd., to 45,000,000 pesos represented by 3,000,000 shares of 15 pesos par value, Joseph O. Hanson, president, announced yesterday in a communication to shareholders. The company's previous authorized capital was 22,500,000 pesos Argentine gold represented by 1,500,000 shares of 15 pesos par value. Stockholders voted the increase at a special meeting last April.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--With the legal battle in the coal strike going into its second week tomorrow, pressure was building up in industry for a settlement that would get coal out of the ground again under private management.

Among the pre-holiday art exhibitions this week will be a showing of the Howard Mansfield collection of Japanese prints at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday and the annual children's holiday fair at the Museum of Modern Art, opening Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP)--The Chicago Cardinals, after exploding for three second-period touchdowns in slightly over two minutes, needed a pay-off pass in the final fourteen seconds to gain a 35-to-28 National Football League victory over the Western Division champion Chicago Bears before a Wrigley Field record crowd of 47,511 to day.

HONOLULU, Dec. 1--Greater losses were suffered by the Hawaiian sugar industry during the seventy-nine-day strike of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union ended Nov. 19 than during the entire war in the Pacific, according to H. Alexander Walker, president of the Hawaiian Sugar Planters Association. In his annual report today...

NANKING, Dec. 1 (AP)--The focal point of China's civil war moved back into Manchuria today. Military sources indicated that the next large-scale battles could be expected there rather than around the Communist capital of Yenan.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1--Unemployment incident to the coal strike was expected to affect 600,000 in the nation by the end of this week, reports from steel companies, railroads and other large employers indicated today. Added to the 400,000 striking miners, these prospective layoffs would raise the idle list to 1,000,000.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1-- Federal labor legislation and State pay increases for teachers were listed today as major topics for discussion at a meeting here tomorrow of the executive committee of the National Conference of Governors. These subjects are expected to come up also at meetings of the larger Council of State Governments later in the week.

LONDON, Dec. 1--A speed record for a commercial flight between New York and London was set today by a Constellation airliner of the American Overseas Air Lines that made a non-stop crossing from New York in ten hours twelve minutes.

When the Pro Arte Quartet was unable to appear last January with the New Friends of Music, Ira A. Hirschmann engaged the Guilet Quartet to pinch-hit for them. The substitute group performed so well that it was re-engaged this season. Late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall it made the first of two scheduled appearances.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman will lead an army of 10,000 volunteer workers in the public solicitation appeal of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, it was announced yesterday. The public appeal phase of the current drive to raise $12,000,000, the largest sum ever sought, will begin on Dec. 9, when "Federation Week" will start. It is expected that 500,000 New Yorkers will be reached.

A temporary order restraining the Equity Corporation from holding a special stockholders' meeting that had been called for tomorrow has been signed by Federal District Judge Alfred C. Coxe, it became known yesterday.
Reports on dwindling coal stockpiles in the city and in New Jersey will be made today to public officials who must determine when more drastic conservation measures will be necessary.
A small forest of Christmas trees decorated with colored aluminum balls was erected yesterday in Herald and Greeley Squares by three department stores in the area.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 1 Rallying strongly in the final ten minutes of play the 1946 AllUnited States team gained a 5-5 tie with the Reserves in the final game of the twenty-fourth national tournament of the United States Field Hockey Association on the grounds of Adelphi College today.

ROME, Dec. 1--The recently formed Right-wing Christian Democratic movement petitioned the executive committee of the Christian Democratic party today to sever all ties with the Communists both in the Government and in the General Confederation of Labor,

Having occupied four houses during its local engagement, "A Flag Is Born" will close Dec. 15 at the Broadway. A week later the attraction is scheduled to begin a Chicago run. Before doing so, Jacob Ben-Ami, who arrived yesterday morning from Buenos Aires, will take over the central role from Luther Adler. Mr. Ben-Ami was present at yesterday's matinee and will succeed Mr. Adler, who has to leave for Hollywood, late this week.

ATLANTIC CITY N.J., Dec. 1 --The Jews of Europe-cannot look for help to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, now in liquidation, nor to its successor, the International Refugee Organization, high government officials of the United States and other countries informed the meeting of the United Jewish Appeal here today.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 1--Most indications available today pointed to general public support in Mississippi for Senator Theodore G. Bilbo in the investigation he will face, starting tomorrow, on charges of inciting intimidation of Negroes during his campaign preceding the Democratic primary in July.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 25 per cent in November compared with the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In October, a decline of 2 per cent was reported.

BERLIN, Dec. 2--Extensive looting in the Russian zone is reliably reported to be coinciding with the departure of veteran troops being sent home for demobilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The Government acted today to swing strategic parts of its 1,500 miles of idle wartime pipelines into almost immediate service to help relieve the fuel shortages caused by the coal strike.
LONDON, Dec. 2--Prof. Harold Laski, noted historian and philosopher and one of the Labor party's outstanding leaders, lost his libel case against The Newark Advertiser in a verdict rendered today.

MINEOLA, L.I, Dec. 2--Ward Beecher Caraway was under the influence of a narcotic and did not know what he was doing at the time of the slaying of Mrs. William Logan, his attorney declared today in his opening address to the jury.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 --The Soviet Union lashed out again today at the proposed 1947 budget for the United Nations, with particular emphasis on radio and motion picture expenses, printing costs and increases in staff salaries.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 --The United Jewish Appeal's national conference here adopted today a quota of $170,000,000 for its 1947 campaign for relief and rehabilitation in European countries, for refugee settlement in Palestine and for refugee adjustment in the United States.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. MOUNT OLYMPUS, at Sea, Dec. 2--Eight ships of the United States Navy sailed into the Atlantic and Pacific today, starting a vast expedition that Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd said before the sailing would probably explore half of the unknown portion of Antarctica.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The War Assets Administration announced today "sweeping changes" in the procedures governing the disposal of surplus property to veterans.

The five-story apartment building at 633 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by George A. Worrell from George H. Kline through Fitzherbert Howell, broker in the transaction. The title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 --The United Kingdom today led other colonial powers in flatly denying Russia's charge that they desired to "annex" trust territories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The War Department is having manpower trouble again and is considering not only a new draft call but a request to extend the Selective Service Act beyond the deadline, set now for May 31, 1947.

Textile converter-jobbers held in violation of Office of Price Administration regulations for exceeding their 1939-41 percentage of jobbing sales and subject to treble damages have been freed of all liability under an agency ruling which invalidated Order No. 8 of MPR-127, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2--Grain markets closed strong on the Chicago Board of Trade after showing weakness early when there was commission house pressure and professional selling on uncertainty as to the Government support program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 --A fourteen-nation subcommittee, appointed by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations to study proposals on the use of the veto by the Security Council, after five hours of discussion this afternoon was no nearer agreement than at the start of the meeting.
The Rev. Dr. Arthur J. Brown, an official of the Presbyterian Board of Missions for fifty-one years, will celebrate his ninetieth, birthday today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2-- Despite the introduction of four Russian amendments, of which two were voted down and a third was modified, a five-point resolution on measures to alleviate the 1947 food shortage was virtually agreed on in today's meeting of the Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 --Senator Tom Connally declared here today that the United States would not "tolerate any veto" that would block the effective functioning of a system of international inspection and control of armaments, including the atomic bomb and other weapons for mass destruction.

CLINTON, N.Y., Dec. 2--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Noble Gleason of this place have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Greeley, to Herbert Clifford Hansen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hansen of Elizabeth, N.J.

The stock market lost yesterday much of its previous optimism over a quick settlement of the bituminous mines strike, although the retreat of prices stemmed mainly from a lack of support rather than outright selling.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (AP)-- Pacific Coast League directors adopted a resolution today asking for immediate recognition as a third major baseball league. The resolution will be presented to the National and American League heads at their meeting here Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--A major portion of the suppressed report of the Senate War Investigating Committee detailing scandals in the United States occupation zone in Germany is devoted to the problem of displaced persons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2-- Constance Bennett has closed a deal to produce and appear in three films for Allied Artists, Inc., newly formed subsidiary of Monogram Pictures, it was learned today.

William B. Benjamin pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to counts of grand larceny and forgery to cover a twentycount indictment arising from frauds totaling $493,000 last year.

In a spirit of compromise the Council of Foreign Ministers yesterday agreed in principle on several disputes over the Italian and Danubian treaties, which they had been struggling for a month to draft.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 5--Walter S. Andrews, who had been with realty firms here for the last thirty-four years and was prominent in the summer colony, died this morning in the Newport Hospital. His age was 74.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The draft holiday was extended through January today, despite lagging voluntary enlistments.

DETROIT, Dec. 5--Thousands of workers began playing a dirgeful monotone on the industrial time clocks of Detroit tonight. The Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company, the greatest... Single concentration of industrial might in the world, had begun to grind to a halt.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 5--After three days' effort, District Attorney James N. Gehrig succeeded in introducing as evidence today parts of a .32 caliber pistol allegedly used by Ward Beecher Caraway in slaying Mrs. William John Logan, and three statements made by the defendant after his arrest.
In a series of capital agreements in their 115th session yesterday, the Council of Foreign Ministers neared the end of the first lap on their long, long trail to peace.

Marcel Cerdan, holder of the middleweight championship of Europe, will make his first start in an American ring tonight when he meets Georgia Abrams of Washington, D.C., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

In view of the increasing shortage of automobile batteries in this city and reports that profiteers are boosting the prices in some cases from 25 to 50 per cent above normal levels, the Automobile Club of New York urged yesterday that motorists practice stringent conservation methods.

Cotton textile distribution will deteriorate rapidly as a result of the rail embargo, even though mill production is able to continue strong for at least sixty days, Worth Street textile men said yesterday.

William K. Jackson, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, called last night for revision of the Wagner Labor Relations Act on the ground that, since its passage eleven years ago, it had been "turned into an anachronism and a monument to injustice in group relationships."
The Chase National Bank of the City of New York today heads a banking group which will offer $23,200,000 of bonds of the City of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--As the contempt convictions of John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers started moving into the higher courts today, the White House announced that President Truman would address the country by radio Sunday night at 9:30, Eastern Standard Time, on the coal strike.

NANKING, Dec. 5--The National Assembly moved an important stage nearer the adoption of a permanent Constitution for China today by voting to cease the general discussion of the Government's draft and start consideration of the different sections of the Constitution.

"So Dark the Night," a mystery melodrama, produced by Columbia, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. Steven Geray, Micheline Cheirel, Eugene Borden, Ann Codee, Egon Brecher and Helen Freeman head the cast. Joseph H. Lewis directed and Ted Richmond produced.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5--Night baseball, a bugbear in the major leagues since Larry MacPhail introduced it in Cincinnati more than a decade ago, again became a major bone of contention today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 30, 1946, totaled 660,911 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Post-war interest in newspaper advertising has increased, especially among men, The Advertising Research Foundation reported yesterday in its summary of readership analyses made of 100 newspapers throughout the country during the last seven years in the Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church granted yesterday the petition of the nine judges of Genreal Sessions Court to compel the City of New York to appropriate sufficient money to pay them additional compensation of $1,000 a year each. The increase brings their salaries to $26,000, making it equal to that received by the justices of the Supreme Court.

The Board of Estimate has now completed its action on the 1947 capital budget, emerging after much hard work with an authorized outlay of $239,911,239, or $282,035 more than was proposed by the City Planning Commission.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on last Wednesday covered a variety of industries and commodities, but repayments held the total increase to $8,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

The national committee of the Communist party terminated a three-day post-election meeting last night after hearing William Z. Foster, national chairman, report that Communists no longer had influence within the government of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The name of Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor of New York and unsuccessful Democratic candidate for the Senate in the November elections, was heard today in speculation as to Eugene Meyer's successor as president of the World Bank. Mr. Meyer resigned yesterday.

Ten years ago the Metropolitan Museum acquired the magnificent collection of Japanese prints formed by the late Howard Mansfield, whose notable gift also included Japanese paintings, pottery, examples of metalwork, lacquer, robes designed for the No dances, masks and printed books.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 (AP) --Endicott P. (Cotty) Davison of Locust Valley, N.Y., a 22-yearold, 210-pound tackle, was elected captain of the 1947 Yale football team today. He succeeds Richard M. Hollingshead 3d of Riverton, N.J., also a tackle.

The stock market demonstrated again yesterday its responsiveness to news on the coal strike by a shift of price movements.

BERLIN, Dec. 5--W.C. Doherty, a vice president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that the divided control of Germany was a "colossal failure." He added that only through unified control could the present unsatisfactory conditions in Germany be corrected.

Herbert L. Satterlee, New York lawyer and philanthropist, received last night the annual medal of merit of the St. Nicholas Society of the City of New York.

SEATTLE, Dec. 5--Charles P. Taft, Cincinnati lawyer and son of the late President, this afternoon was elected first layman president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. Mr. Taft, who is an Episcopalian, succeeds Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist, of New York.

Janet Fairbank, soprano, was heard in her annual recital devoted to contemporary songs, last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her program contained American offerings by Ned Rorem, Everett B. Helm, Paul Bowles and Wilda.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 5--In hourlong concerted attacks, Zionist terrorists struck tonight in at least four different parts of Jerusalem.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5--Charles Mittendorf Cohn, chairman of the board of directors of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, which serves an area of 2,300 square miles with a population of more than 1,500,000 persons, died here today in Union Memorial Hospital of a cerebral thrombosis after an illness of a day. His age was 73.

Smith, chairman of the Maritime Commission, pointed out tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 5-- The Russians are probably far behind in atomic research, said Professor Otto Hahn, German winner of the 1944 Nobel award in chemistry, upon his arrival here from Goettingen, Germany, today. St. Martin Parish, La., announced yesterday that on Dec. 20 it will offer $275,000 of public improvement bonds bearing interest of not more than 4 per cent. Dated Jan. 15, 1947, the issue will come due Jan. 15 from 1949 to 1967.

The archers seem to have multiplied this season, and reports from a half dozen States indicate that the percentage of deer kills among archers is just about as high as it is among those who hunt with the shotgun or rifle.

The former residential property of William F. Kenny in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, at the northeast corner of Shore Road and Oliver Street, has been purchased by Realty Associates as the site for an extensive apartment house project when materials are available.

More than 80 per cent of the 127,000 women employed in the laundry, restaurant and hotel industries of New York State earn less than enough to maintain "a minimum adequate standard of living," the latest surveys of the women's division of the State Labor Department showed yesterday.
Small business properties continue to attract major attention in Manhattan realty trading. Several deals involving parcels of this type were reported yesterday.
